section.text: It shall be unlawful for any person or persons, who are remaining, standing, loitering, or wandering about at any public place or place open or legally accessible to the public in such a manner as to beckon to, or repeatedly stop, or repeatedly attempt to engage passersby in conversation, or repeatedly stop or attempt to stop motor vehicles, or repeatedly interfere with the free passage of other persons, for the purpose or with the intention of either engaging in and/or promoting prostitution, lewdness, or assignation, to disobey a request by a police officer to move on.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Method not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a civil citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any person violating any of the provisions of this Part shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or imprisonment in jail not exceeding 12 months, or to both fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court.

section.heading: "Certified prostitution-free zone" defined.
section.text: A "certified prostitution-free zone" is a geographical area of Baltimore City certified as such by the Police Commissioner, encompassing specified segments of streets, alleys, walkways, parks, public access areas in residential apartment structures, places of public accommodations, schools, bus stations, train depots, and taxi stands.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Police Commissioner may establish, alter, recertify, or terminate the certification of prostitution-free zones from time to time.

para.heading: 3-month limit.
para.text: Provided, however, that any certification will expire 3 months after the date of its certification unless recertified for an additional 3 months prior to expiration.

para.heading: Conditions for recertification.
para.text: The Commissioner may certify or recertify a prostitution-free zone after the two 3-month periods provided herein if:
the conditions in § 27-13 are met; and
those findings indicate that the conduct prohibited herein has returned to that particular public place or place open or legally accessible to the public.

section.heading: Considerations for certification.
section.text: To determine whether to certify an area as a "prostitution-free zone", the Police Commissioner shall consider the following:

para.text: arrests or other statistical criteria for reporting crime which are accepted and relied upon by law enforcement agencies and which indicate a disproportionately high occurrence of prostitution in the proposed prostitution-free zone;
reliable, objective, and verifiable information which indicates that prostitution is occurring in the proposed prostitution-free zone; and

any other verifiable information acceptable by law enforcement agencies that indicates to the Police Commissioner that the health or safety of the residents that live in or near the proposed prostitution-free zone is endangered by the activity of prostitution.

para.heading: Pre-certification notices.
para.text: Prior to certifying or recertifying a prostitution-free zone, the Police Commissioner shall:
cause to be published in 1 or more newspapers of general circulation in Baltimore City, at least 1 week prior to certification, a listing of specific areas to be certified;

provide written notice to the Mayor and the President and members of the City Council, not less than 1 week prior to certification, of the specific area to be certified, including the boundaries of the area and the date when certification will begin; and

at least 3 days prior to certification, publish a notice of certification in the area to be certified. Publication shall be by use of mass media, community newsletters or newspapers, community relations councils, by posting notices on city-owned poles or other structures in the area, posting notices, after obtaining permission, in local shops and shop windows and on utility poles, or any other means deemed appropriate.

para.heading: Dissemination of list of zones.
para.text: The Commissioner shall disseminate to all police enforcement personnel a current list of certified prostitution-free zones.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct.
section.text: It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter or remain at any public place or place open or legally accessible to the public within a certified prostitution-free zone, as herein provided, if the person intentionally engages in or promotes prostitution, lewdness, or assignation.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Method not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a civil citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any person violating any of the provisions of this Part shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or imprisonment in jail not exceeding 90 days, or both fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: It is unlawful for any person to ride on a bumper, fender, or any exterior portion of any public passenger motor bus or other common carrier.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person violating the provisions of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be subject to a fine not exceeding $10.

section.heading: Scope of subtitle.
section.text: The provisions of this subtitle apply only to wheeled carts and other similar devices which have the name and address of the owners thereof clearly marked thereon.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct.
section.text: Any person who:

para.text: removes from the premises of any grocery store, store, or market any wheeled cart or other similar device belonging to the owner of such grocery store, store, or market and used for the purpose of assembling or carrying materials there purchased;
destroys, mutilates, or damages any such wheeled cart or other device;
abandons any such wheeled cart or device upon the streets, highways, or alleys of the City of Baltimore; or
has in his possession any such wheeled cart or other device away from the premises of the owner of such wheeled cart or device,
is guilty of a misdemeanor.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Upon conviction thereof, he is subject to a fine of not more than $100 for each such offense.

container.heading: Minors - Sales in Proximity to Liquor Store

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Close proximity ....
para.text: "Close proximity to liquor store" means located:
on the premises of a liquor store; or
in a structure that immediately adjoins a liquor store and has direct access to the interior of that liquor store.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, "liquor store" means any establishment that sells alcoholic beverages for off-premise consumption.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Liquor store" includes a licensee who holds one of the following off-sale licenses:
a Class A beer, wine, and liquor license;
a Class A-2 beer, wine, and liquor off-sale package goods license; and

a Class B-D-7 beer, wine, and liquor license if, on an annual basis, the Class B-D-7 licensee's average daily receipts from sales of alcoholic beverages for off-premise consumption exceeds 40% of the licensee's total average daily receipts from all sales (on-sale and off-sale) of alcoholic beverages.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Liquor store" does not include:

an establishment that sells non-alcoholic products (e.g., groceries or other food items, paper goods, home and office supplies, and other goods or merchandise) the average daily receipts from which sales, on an annual basis, exceed 80% of the establishment's total average daily receipts; or
a licensee who holds:
an on-sale license (other than a Class B-D-7 license included under paragraph (2)(iii) of this subsection); or
one of the following off-sale licenses:
Class A beer and light wine license (off-sale); and
Class A2 light wine license (on- and off-sale).

section.heading: Sales to minors.
section.text: No person in close proximity to a liquor store may sell any food, goods, supplies, or other merchandise (even if non-alcoholic) to any minor.

section.heading: Inducing minor to purchase.
section.text: No person may request or induce a minor to purchase any food, goods, supplies, or other merchandise in violation of § 32-3 {"Sales to minors"} of this subtitle.

section.heading: False representation by minor.
section.text: No minor may knowingly and falsely represent her- or himself to any person as being 18 years old or older for the purpose of purchasing any food, goods, supplies, or other merchandise in violation of § 32-3 {"Sales to minors"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates a provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to the penalties specified in this section.
For a violation of § 32-3 {"Sales to minors"} or § 32-4 {"Inducing minor to purchase"}, the penalty is a fine of not more than $500 for each offense.
For a violation of § 32-5 {"False representation by minor"}, the penalty is as follows:
for a 1st conviction, a fine of not more than $100 for each offense; and
for a 2nd or subsequent conviction, a fine of not more than $250 for each offense.

section.heading: "Minor" defined.
section.text: In this subtitle, "minor" applies to every individual under 21 years of age, except to bona fide employees in the course of their employment and whose employment is not prohibited by the State Alcoholic Beverages Article.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: It shall be unlawful for any minor:
to attempt to purchase alcoholic beverages; or
to drink or have in his or her possession any alcoholic beverages:
in any public place; or
on any public highway.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof:
shall be subject to a fine not exceeding $100 for the minor's 1st conviction; and

for the 2nd or any subsequent conviction thereof, the minor shall be subject to a fine not exceeding $250 or to imprisonment in jail for a period not exceeding 60 days or both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: It shall be unlawful for any minor knowingly and falsely to represent himself to be 21 years of age to any licensed person engaged in the sale of alcoholic beverages, for the purpose of procuring or having such alcoholic beverages furnished to him by sale, gift, or otherwise.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof:
shall be subject to a fine not exceeding $100 for his 1st conviction; and

for the 2nd or any subsequent conviction thereof, the minor shall be subject to a fine not exceeding $250 or to imprisonment in jail for a period not exceeding 60 days or both such fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: It shall be unlawful for any person:
to request or induce a minor to purchase or to attempt to purchase any alcoholic beverages; or
to give to, supply with, or in any way furnish to a minor, on any street or public way or in any place of public resort, any alcoholic beverage.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not more than $500 for each and every such violation.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Establishment.
para.text: "Establishment" means:
any privately-owned place of business carried on for a profit; or
any place of amusement or entertainment to which the public is invited.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Operator" means any person operating, managing, or conducting any establishment.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: When used in any clause imposing a penalty, the term "operator":
as applied to a partnership or association, includes the partners or members thereof; and
as applied to a corporation, includes the officers thereof.

para.heading: Parent.
para.text: "Parent" means:
any natural parent of a minor;
a guardian; or
any person 18 years old or older who is legally responsible for the care and custody of a minor.

para.heading: Public place.
para.text: "Public place" means any public street, highway, road, alley, park, playground, wharf, dock, public building, or vacant lot.

para.heading: Remain.
para.text: "Remain" means to loiter, idle, wander, stroll, or play in or upon.

para.heading: Youth Connection Center.
para.text: "Youth Connection Center" means a place, as established or designated by the City, to which minors believed to be in violation of § 34-3 {"Prohibited conduct of minors – Nighttime curfew"} or § 34-4 {"Prohibited conduct of minors – Daytime curfew"} of this subtitle can be taken to determine an appropriate course of action.

section.heading: Legislative findings.
section.text: The Mayor and City Council find that:

para.text: An emergency has been created by a substantial increase in the number and in the seriousness of crimes committed by minors against persons and property within the City, and this has created a menace to the preservation of public peace, safety, health, morals, and welfare.

The increase in juvenile delinquency has been caused in part by the large number of minors who are permitted to remain in public places and in certain establishments during night hours without adult supervision, and during daylight hours at times when, by law, they are required to attend school.

Education is the foundation of success and a productive life. The City of Baltimore provides the educational system and its staff, but the cooperation of students and their parents determines the productivity of the educational system. Late evening activity by certain of our youth prevents them from concentrating in class or, even worse, causes their absence from class. This, together with truancy, has risen alarmingly in recent years and youth is thus deprived of a necessary basic education. The rate of absenteeism has risen alarmingly in recent years while the achievement rate has rapidly decreased. The end result is an increase in failures and dropouts, frustration, malcontent, antisocial conduct, and, for many, a future without promise.

The problem of juvenile delinquency can be reduced by regulating the hours during which minors may remain in public places and in certain establishments without adult supervision, and by imposing certain duties and responsibilities upon the parents or other adult persons who have care and custody of minors.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct of minors – Nighttime curfew.

para.heading: Scope of section.
para.text: This section does not apply to a minor:
accompanied by the minor's parent;
exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, or the right of assembly;
in a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel;
engaged in an employment activity or going to or returning home from an employment activity, without any detour or stop;
involved in an emergency;
on the sidewalk abutting the minor's residence or abutting the residence of a next-door neighbor if the neighbor did not complain to the Police Department about the minor's presence; or

attending or, without any detour or stop, going to or returning from an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the City of Baltimore, a civic organization, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct – Minors less than 14 years old.
para.text: No minor less than 14 years of age may remain in or about any public place or any establishment between the hours of 9 p.m. on any day and 6 a.m. of the following day.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct – Minors at least 14 but less than 17 years old.

para.text: From and including 12:01 a.m. on the Friday preceding Memorial Day each year through 12 midnight of the last Sunday of August each year, no minor at least 14, but less than 17, years of age may remain in or about any public place or any establishment between the hours of 11 p.m. on any day and 6 a.m. of the following day.
For the remainder of the calendar year, no minor at least 14, but less than 17, years of age may remain in or about any public place or any establishment:
between the hours of 11 p.m. on a Friday and 6:00 a.m. of the following Saturday;
between the hours of 11 p.m. on a Saturday and 6:00 a.m. of the following Sunday; or
between the hours of 10 p.m. and 6 a.m. of the following day, on any other day of the week.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct of minors – Daytime curfew.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) of this section, no minor under the age of 16 may remain in or about any public place or any establishment between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 3 p.m. on any day during which the minor is required to be in school.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: Subsection (a) of this section does not apply if:
the minor has written proof from school authorities excusing his or her attendance at that particular time; or
the minor is accompanied by the minor's parent or by a person 21 years old or older; or
the minor is traveling to or from school.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct of parents, guardians, etc.
section.text: It is unlawful for the parent of any minor to knowingly permit or, by insufficient control, to allow that minor to be in or about any public place or any establishment if that minor's presence would violate § 34-3 {"Prohibited conduct of minors – Nighttime curfew"} or § 34-4 {"Prohibited conduct of minors – Daytime curfew"} of this subtitle.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct of establishments.
section.text: No operator of an establishment or his agents or employees may knowingly permit any minor to remain on the premises of that establishment if that minor's presence would violate § 34-3 {"Prohibited conduct of minors – Nighttime curfew"} or § 34-4 {"Prohibited conduct of minors – Daytime curfew"} of this subtitle.

section.heading: Detention of minor not an arrest.
section.text: Detention of a minor under this subtitle is not considered an arrest and does not create a criminal record for the minor under State law.

para.heading: Identification.
para.text: If a police officer has reason to believe that a minor is in violation of § 34-3 {"Prohibited conduct of minors – Nighttime curfew"} or § 34-4 {"Prohibited conduct of minors – Daytime curfew"} of this subtitle, the police officer shall seek to obtain from the minor:
the minor's name, address, school or other valid identification, and age; and
the name of the minor's parent or parents.
For a minor believed to be in violation of § 34-4 {"Prohibited conduct of minors – Daytime curfew"}, the minor shall be taken, as appropriate, to:
the minor's school;
a Youth Connection Center; or
the minor's home.
If the minor is taken to school or to a Youth Connection Center, the school or center, as the case may be, shall:
notify a parent about the violation of this subtitle; and
take appropriate measures to reduce the probability that the minor will commit a subsequent violation of this subtitle.
For a minor believed to be in violation of § 34-3 {"Prohibited conduct of minors – Nighttime curfew"}, the minor shall be taken, as appropriate, to:
the minor's home; or
a Youth Connection Center.
If the minor is taken to a Youth Connection Center, the facility shall:
notify a parent or an adult brother, sister, aunt, uncle, or grandparent to come and take charge of the minor;
notify a parent about the violation of this subtitle; and
take appropriate measures to reduce the probability that the minor will commit a subsequent violation of this subtitle.

If the minor is taken to a Youth Connection Center and, by 6 a.m. of the following morning, no parent or adult brother, sister, aunt, uncle, or grandparent can be located or none come and take charge of the minor, the minor shall be, as appropriate:
taken to the minor's home;
referred to or placed in the custody of the Baltimore City Department of Social Services; or
released from the Youth Connection Center.

para.heading: Maximum period of detention.
para.text: In no event may a minor be detained for more than 24 hours if the minor is charged solely with a violation of this subtitle.

para.heading: Notices.
para.text: Notice is presumed to be received by a parent if deposited in a depository for mailing United States Mail, properly addressed and with first-class postage paid. The mailing may be shown by the records of the sending agency made in the regular course of its business.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, § 34-5 {"Prohibited conduct of parents, guardians, etc."} of this subtitle and § 34-6 {"Prohibited conduct of establishments"} of this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a civil citation to enforce those sections does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy authorized by law.
A parent who violates § 34-5 {"Prohibited conduct of parents, guardians, etc."} of this subtitle for the 1st time may be issued:
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}; or

if the parent agrees to attend family counseling sessions with the minor at an agency approved by the City of Baltimore, a notice that a civil citation will be issued if the counseling sessions are not completed.

A parent who violates § 34-5 {"Prohibited conduct of parents, guardians, etc."} of this subtitle after having received notice under § 34-8 {"Enforcement"} of a prior violation or after having been issued a civil citation or a notice under paragraph (1) of this subsection for a prior violation is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to 1 or more of the following, in the discretion of the court:
a fine not to exceed $500 and costs; and
community service.

para.heading: Operator of establishment.
para.text: Any operator of an establishment and any agent or employee of any operator who violates any provision of § 34-6 {"Prohibited conduct of establishments"}of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $500 for each violation.

para.heading: Separate offenses.
para.text: Each violation of a provision of this subtitle constitutes a separate offense.

section.heading: Continuing evaluation.
section.text: The Mayor and City Council shall continue evaluating and updating this subtitle through methods including but not limited to:

para.text: Annually, on or before February 1 of each year,the Police Commissioner must report to the Mayor and City Council:
on the effect of this subtitle on crimes committed by and against minors;
the number of warnings issued and arrests of minors, parents, and operators hereunder; and
such other information as the Mayor and City Council may request.

On a regular basis, the Mayor and City Council shall receive informal reports of all exceptional cases hereunder and advisory opinions for consideration in further updating and continuing evaluation of this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: As used in this section, the following words have the meanings indicated unless the context dearly indicates otherwise.

para.heading: Controlled dangerous substance.
para.text: "Controlled dangerous substance" means a controlled dangerous substance as defined in the Article 27, Subtitle "Health - Controlled Dangerous Substances" of the Maryland Code.

para.heading: Parent.
para.text: "Parent" includes guardian.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: An adult, including a parent, shall not:
buy a controlled dangerous substance from a minor;
sell or induce a minor to use or possess a controlled dangerous substance; or
cause to hold, look out, deliver, transport, or hold money or drugs, or in any way conspire to induce a minor to violate the provisions of this section.

para.heading: Lack of knowledge no defense.
para.text: A person charged with a violation of this section shall not use his or her lack of knowledge of the minor's age as a defense in the prosecution of any case under this section.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction may be fined not more than $1,000 or imprisoned for a mandatory minimum period of not less than 60 days or not more than 1 year or both fine and imprisonment.

para.heading: "Glue ...".
para.text: As used in this section, the phrase "glue containing a solvent having the property or releasing toxic vapors or fumes" shall mean and include any glue, cement, or other adhesive containing 1 or more of the following chemical compounds: acetone, and acetate, benzene, butyl alcohol, ethyl alcohol, ethylene dichloride, isopropyl alcohol, methyl alcohol, methyl ethyl ketone, pentachlorophenol, petroleum ether, or toluene.

para.heading: Carbon tetrachloride.
para.text: As used in this section, the phrase "carbon tetrachloride" shall mean any product containing, as its primary ingredient, carbon tetrachloride.

para.heading: Inhalation of glue or carbon tetrachloride.

para.text: No person shall, for the purpose of causing a condition of intoxication, inebriation, excitement, stupefaction, or the dulling of his brain or nervous system, intentionally smell or inhale the fumes of any glue and carbon tetrachloride product containing a solvent having the property of releasing toxic vapors or fumes.
Providing that nothing in this section shall be interpreted as applying to the inhalation of any anesthetic used for medical or dental purposes.

para.heading: Use or possession of glue or carbon tetrachloride.

para.text: No person shall, for the purpose of causing a condition of intoxication, inebriation, excitement, stupefaction, or the dulling of his brain or nervous system, intentionally use or have in his possession for the purpose of using any glue and carbon tetrachloride product containing a solvent having the property of releasing toxic vapors or fumes.
Providing that nothing in this section shall be interpreted as applying to the inhalation of any anesthetic used for medical or dental purposes.

para.heading: Sale, etc., to minor of glue and carbon tetrachloride.
para.text: It shall be unlawful for any person, excepting a parent or legal guardian of a minor, to sell, offer to sell, transfer, or act as an agent for the sale or transfer to any person under the age of 21 years any tube or other container of glue and carbon tetrachloride product containing a solvent having the property of releasing toxic vapors or fumes.

para.heading: Sale, etc., to minor of spray paints, etc.
para.text: It shall be unlawful for any person, excepting a parent or legal guardian of a minor, to sell, offer to sell, transfer, or act as an agent for the sale or transfer to any person under the age of 21 years any paint, enamel, lacquer, or other coloring matter in pressurized spray containers.

para.heading: Sale, etc., to minor of certain cleaning fluids.
para.text: It shall be unlawful for any person, excepting a parent or legal guardian of a minor, to sell, offer to sell, transfer, or act as an agent for the sale or transfer to any person under the age of 21 years any type of cleaning fluid containing 1 or more of the following chemical compounds: acetone, and acetate, benzene, butyl alcohol, ethyl alcohol, ethylene dichloride, isopropyl alcohol, methyl, alcohol, methyl ethyl ketone, pentachlorophenol, petroleum ether, or toluene.

Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100 nor more than $500 or by imprisonment for not more than 6 months, or both, for each offense.
In addition to a fine or imprisonment or both or in lieu of a fine or imprisonment or both, a judge may sentence a person convicted under this section to perform community service.

para.heading: Sale, etc., to minor.
para.text: It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, transfer, or act as an agent for the sale or transfer to any person under the age of 18 years any product containing as its primary ingredient butyl nitrite, amyl nitrite, isobutyl nitrite, isoamyl nitrite or their congenors, except when prescribed by a physician.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100 nor more than $500 or by imprisonment for not more than 6 months, or both, for each offense.

para.heading: Transfers to minor.
para.text: It is unlawful for any person to sell, exchange, give, or loan any pressurized spray can containing any substance commonly known as paint, or containing any other opaque liquid capable of being propelled by the aerosol can, to any minor under the age of 18 years, if such sale, gift, or loan is with the intent to induce or with the knowledge that the minor will use the aerosol spray for the purpose of defacing, damaging, injuring or in any other manner unlawfully applying the spray substance to any personal or real property of another.

para.heading: Possession by minor.
para.text: It is unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to have in his or her possession any pressurized spray can containing any substance commonly known as paint or containing any other opaque liquid capable of being propelled by the pressurized can, with the intent to deface, injure, damage, or in any other manner lawfully apply the sprayed substance to any personal or real property of another, while on public property or upon private property without the consent of the owner of such private property.

para.heading: Inhalation.
para.text: It is unlawful for any person to deliberately smell or inhale such excessive quantifies of the substance or chemical emitted from a pressurized spray can of paint as cause conditions of intoxication, inebriation, excitement, stupefaction, or dulling the brain or nervous system.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500 for each offense.

para.heading: Harmful to minors.
para.text: "Harmful to minors" means that quality of representation of nudity, sexual conduct, sexual excitement, or sadomasochistic abuse that:
predominantly appeals to the prurient, shameful, or morbid interest of young persons;
is patently offensive to prevailing standards in the adult community as a whole with respect to what is suitable material for young persons; and
is utterly without redeeming social importance for young persons.
"Knowingly" means having general knowledge of, or reason to know, or a belief or ground for belief which warrants further inspection or inquiry or both:
the character and content of any material described herein which is reasonably susceptible of examination by the defendant; and
the age of the minor.
Provided, however, that an honest mistake shall constitute an excuse from liability hereunder if the defendant made a reasonable bona fide attempt to ascertain the true age of such minor.

para.heading: Nudity.
para.text: "Nudity" means:
the showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area, or buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering; or
the showing of the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering of any part below the top of the nipple; or
the depiction of covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state.

para.heading: Sadomasochistic abuse.
para.text: "Sadomasochistic abuse" means:
flagellation or torture by or upon a person clothed in undergarments, a mask, or a bizarre costume; or
the condition of being fettered, bound, or otherwise physically restrained on the part of one who is so clothed.

para.heading: Sexual conduct.
para.text: "Sexual conduct" means acts of masturbation, sexual intercourse, or physical contact with a person's clothed or unclothed genitals, pubic area, buttocks, or, if the person is a female, breast.

para.heading: Sexual excitement.
para.text: "Sexual excitement" means the condition of human male or female genitals in a discernible state of sexual stimulation or arousal.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct.
section.text: It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to sell, exhibit, or transfer to a minor:

para.text: any picture, photograph, drawing, sculpture, film, or similar visual representation or image of a person or portion of the human body which:
depicts nudity, sexual conduct, or sadomasochistic abuse; and
is harmful to minors; or
any book, pamphlet, magazine, printed matter however reproduced, or sound recording which:
contains any matter enumerated in item (1) immediately above or explicit and detailed verbal descriptions or narrative accounts of sexual excitement, sexual conduct, or sadomasochistic abuse; and
taken as a whole, is harmful to minors.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any person violating any of the provisions of this subtitle shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100 nor more than $500 or by imprisonment for not more than 12 months, or both, for each offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, "person" has the meaning stated in § 1-107 of the City Code's General Provisions Article.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: Every officer, trustee, director, agent, partner, member, or employee of a corporation, partnership, or association who directly or indirectly engages in any of the acts prohibited by this subtitle or who assists the corporation, partnership, or association in any of those prohibited acts shall be subject to the penalties imposed by this subtitle.

para.heading: Parents and guardians excluded.
para.text: No parent or duly appointed guardian may be proceeded against under this subtitle for any alleged mistreatment or abuse of his or her own child or children or child or children for whom he or she has been appointed guardian.

section.heading: Misappropriation of minor's property.
section.text: Any person having the custody of any minor child or children, and who shall appropriate to his own use or for his personal gain or profit any sum of money or any valuable article contributed or given for the support or maintenance of said minor child or children shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction of said offense by a court of competent jurisdiction, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $300, or imprisonment for not more than 30 days, or both fine and imprisonment.

section.heading: General neglect; inducing to beg.
section.text: Any person who shall induce a minor child to beg or ask alms, or any person having the custody of any minor child or children who shall refuse or neglect to provide food, clothing, housing facilities, or medical attention sufficient to preserve the health of such child or children, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction of said offense by a court of competent jurisdiction, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $300, or imprisonment for not more than 30 days, or both.

section.heading: Child left unattended in vehicle.
section.text: Any person, having the care or custody of any child under the age of 11 years who shall cause or permit the child to remain in a motor vehicle while not attended or accompanied in that motor vehicle by a person at least 13 years of age or more shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be subject to a fine of not more than $500 or imprisonment for not more than 30 days, or both fine and imprisonment.

section.heading: Enjoining custody.
section.text: Any person convicted of violating the provisions of this subtitle may be enjoined from:

para.text: receiving or having the custody of any minor child or children; or
acting as officer or agent of any association, corporation, or other organization formed, operated, or maintained for the purpose of having the custody of or caring for any minor child or children.

section.heading: Enforcement by Social Services.
section.text: It shall be the duty of the Department of Social Services to:

para.text: promptly investigate any complaint of a violation of the provisions of this subtitle;
prosecute any person so violating the said provisions; and
whenever they shall deem proper, seek the issuance of an injunction as above provided.

section.heading: Application of subtitle.
section.text: This subtitle shall not be construed to repeal any existing provision of law, but shall be in addition to any existing provisions of law on this subject.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: Except as otherwise specified in this section, no person may, by any means, solicit, coax, entice, or lure any minor to enter into any vehicle, regardless of whether the person knows the age of the minor.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: This section does not apply to:
a person who has express or implied permission from the minor's parent, guardian, or other legal custodian for the activity; or
a law enforcement officer, medic, firefighter, or other person who undertakes the activity:
in response to a bona fide emergency situation; or
otherwise in the reasonable belief that it was necessary to preserve the health, safety, or welfare of the minor.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for not more than 12 months or both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, "replica gun" means any toy, imitation, facsimile, or replica pistol, revolver, shotgun, rifle, air rifle, B-B gun, pellet gun, machine gun, or other simulated weapon, which because of its color, size, shape, or other characteristics, can reasonably be perceived to be a real firearm.

para.heading: Exclusion.
para.text: "Replica gun" does not include any toy, imitation, facsimile, or replica firearm that is in compliance with U.S. Code Title 15, Chapter 76, § 5001 {"Penalties for entering into commerce of imitation firearms"} and its implementing regulations in 15 C.F.R. § 272.3 {"Marking of Toy, Look–Alike and Imitation Firearms: Approved markings"}.

section.heading: Possession prohibited.
section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, no person may own, carry, or possess a replica gun in the City of Baltimore.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: § 39-2 {"Possession prohibited"} of this subtitle does not apply to a replica gun if the replica gun is:
actively being transported in intrastate, interstate, or foreign commerce; or
used primarily for:

the production of a television program, a theatrical or motion picture presentation, or a historical reenactment, provided the use complies with all applicable laws, rules, or regulations concerning the use;
a firearm training class taught by a certified qualified firearm instructor pursuant to Maryland law;
competitions, or in training for competitions, that test the shooting skills of competitors;
display or use on real property owned by the owner of a replica gun, provided the display or use complies with all applicable laws, rules, or regulations concerning the display or use; or
paintball, provided the use complies with City Code Article 19, § 59-26 {"Gas- or air-pellet guns"}.

para.heading: Required storage when not in use.
para.text: A replica gun must be stored in a locked case or affixed to a wall at all times when not in use for an exempt use under paragraph (a)(2) of this section in order to qualify for the exemption.

section.heading: Seizure and forfeiture authorized.
section.text: A replica gun is subject to seizure and forfeiture if it is found in violation of this subtitle.

para.heading: When warrant not needed.
para.text: A police officer need not have a warrant to seize a replica gun if:
the police officer has probable cause to believe the replica gun is in violation of this subtitle; and
a warrant is not constitutionally required under the circumstances.

para.heading: Removal of replica gun.
para.text: Whenever a police officer seizes a replica gun under this subtitle, the police officer may cause it to be moved to a place designated by the Police Commissioner.

para.heading: Replica gun not repleviable.
para.text: A replica gun seized under this subtitle is not repleviable and remains in the custody of the Police Department, subject only to the orders and decrees of the court or official with jurisdiction over it.

para.heading: Police to refer case.
para.text: Promptly after seizure, the City Solicitor must be notified in writing of the facts and circumstances supporting the seizure.
On receiving the report, the Solicitor must conduct an independent review of the facts and circumstances surrounding the seizure.

If the Solicitor finds sufficient evidence that the alleged replica gun was in violation of this subtitle, the Solicitor must notify the replica gun's owner, by registered or certified mail, of the seizure and of the owners right to seek the return of the replica gun under § 39-7 {"Judicial review"} of this subtitle.
If, on the other hand, the Solicitor finds that there is insufficient evidence to prove a violation, the Solicitor must surrender the alleged replica gun to the owner on the owner' request.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The owner of a replica gun seized under this subtitle may petition the District Court for Baltimore City for the return of the replica gun.

para.heading: Time allowed for petition.
para.text: A petition under this section must be filed within 30 days of the notification required by § 39-6(b)(2).

para.heading: Court to provide for disposition.
para.text: If the court determines that the replica gun should be forfeited, the court may order the replica gun forfeited to the City or provide other means to dispose of the replica gun.

para.heading: When deemed forfeited without petition.
para.text: A replica gun that has been seized by the City is deemed forfeited to the City if the replica gun owner has not timely filed in the District Court for the return of the replica gun under § 39-7 {"Judicial review"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: City disposal of forfeited replica.
para.text: A replica gun that has been forfeited to the City must be destroyed.

section.heading: Order of release.
section.text: If, after a full hearing, the court determines that the replica gun should not be forfeited, the court shall order the replica gun released.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, § 39-2 of this Subtitle may be enforced by issuance of a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a civil citation to enforce § 39-2 of this Subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

section.heading: Criminal penalties for 3rd or subsequent offense.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle after having twice previously been found to have violated this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for not more than 30 days or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following words have the meaning indicated.

para.heading: Department.
para.text: "Department" means the Department of Transportation.
"Dirt bike" means, except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, any motorcycle or similar vehicle that is not registered under the Maryland Vehicle Law.
"Dirt bike" includes:
a minibike;
an all-terrain vehicle of either the 3- or 4-wheel variety; and
except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, any other motorcycle or similar vehicle that is not eligible for registration under the Maryland Vehicle Law.
"Dirt bike" does not include:
a moped, as defined in State Transportation Article § 11-134.1; or
a motor scooter, as defined in State Transportation Article § 11-134.5.
"Minibike" means, except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a motor vehicle that:
has a saddle for the use of the rider;
is designed to travel on not more than 3 wheels in contact with the ground;
is not eligible for registration under the Maryland Vehicle Law; and
has:
a 10-inch (254 mm) or less nominal wheel-rim diameter;
40 inches or less wheel base;
25 inches or less seat height, measured at the lowest point on the top of the seat cushion without rider; or
a propelling engine with piston displacement of 50 cc or less.
"Minibike" does not include:
a moped, as defined in State Transportation Article § 11-134.1; or
a motor scooter, as defined in State Transportation Article § 11-134.5.
"Motorcycle or similar vehicle" means any motor vehicle that is designed to travel on not more than 3 wheels in contact with ground.
"Motorcycle or similar vehicle" includes a minibike.

para.heading: Unregistered motorcycle or similar vehicle.
para.text: "Unregistered motorcycle or similar vehicle" means a motorcycle or similar vehicle that:
is eligible for registration under the Maryland Vehicle Law; but
is not in fact registered.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply to any of the following while being used for their designed purposes:
tractors;
snowblowers;
lawn mowers;
wheel chairs; or
golf carts.

para.heading: Government vehicles.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply to any vehicle owned and operated by an agency or instrumentality of Federal, State, City, or other local government.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Department of Transportation may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.heading: Driving or riding vehicle.
para.text: No person may drive or ride any dirt bike or any unregistered motorcycle or similar vehicle on any public or private property that is located in Baltimore City or, wherever located, that is owned or regulated by the City.

para.heading: Possessing unimmobilized vehicle.
para.text: No person may own, control, possess, or have custody of any dirt bike or any unregistered motorcycle or similar vehicle in Baltimore City unless the vehicle is securely locked or otherwise immobilized by a wheel clamp or other object, device, method, or mechanism, whether attached to the vehicle or not, that:
prevents the vehicle from being freely moved; and
cannot be removed or deactivated without the assistance of the vehicle's owner.

section.heading: Permitting another to drive or ride.
section.text: No owner or other person in control or custody of a dirt bike or an unregistered motorcycle or similar vehicle may permit it to be driven or ridden by any other person on any public or private property that is located in Baltimore City or, wherever located, that is owned or regulated by the City.

section.heading: Parents and guardians.
section.text: No parent or guardian of a minor may knowingly permit the minor to violate any provision of § 40-6 or § 40-7 of this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: No service station nor any other person may sell, transfer, or dispense motor fuel for delivery into any dirt bike or into any unregistered motorcycle or similar vehicle.
In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this section may be enforced by issuance of a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.
The issuance of a civil citation to enforce this section does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

annotations.annotation: Chapters 114 and 115, Acts of 2010, enacted state legislation that, among other things, imposes additional penalties on persons dispensing motor fuel into a dirt bike (State Transportation Article § 21-1128 and § 27-101(dd)) and requires service stations in Baltimore City to post signs of the State and City prohibitions relating to dispensing motor fuel for dirt bikes (State Business Regulation Article § 10-503).

para.heading: Grounds for seizure.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a dirt bike or unregistered motorcycle or similar vehicle is subject to seizure and forfeiture if it is used in violation of this subtitle.

para.heading: Defense.
para.text: A vehicle may not be forfeited under this subtitle solely because of an act or omission by a person other than the vehicle's owner committed or omitted while the vehicle was unlawfully in that other person's possession.

para.heading: When warrant not needed.
para.text: A police officer need not have a warrant to seize a vehicle if:
the police officer has probable cause to believe the vehicle has been used in violation of this subtitle; and
a warrant is not constitutionally required under the circumstances.

para.heading: Removal of vehicle.
para.text: Whenever a police officer seizes a vehicle under this subtitle, the police officer may cause it to be moved to a place designated by the Police Commissioner.

para.heading: Vehicle not repleviable.
para.text: A vehicle seized under this subtitle is not repleviable and remains in the custody of the Police Department, subject only to the orders and decrees of the court or official with jurisdiction over it.

para.heading: Police to refer case.
para.text: Promptly after seizure, the Police Department shall notify the City Solicitor in writing of the facts and circumstances supporting the seizure.
On receiving the report, the Solicitor shall conduct an independent review of the facts and circumstances surrounding the seizure.

If the Solicitor finds sufficient evidence that the vehicle was used in violation of this subtitle, the Solicitor shall notify the vehicle's owner, by registered or certified mail, of the seizure and of the City's intent to institute forfeiture proceedings.
If, on the other hand, the Solicitor finds that there is insufficient evidence to prove violation, the Solicitor shall surrender the vehicle to the owner on the owner's request.

para.heading: Filing; copies to parties in interest.
para.text: If the Solicitor determines that the vehicle should be forfeited, the Solicitor shall, within 90 days after the seizure of the vehicle:
file a forfeiture petition in a court of competent jurisdiction, in the name of the City against the vehicle, as designated by make, model, year, and motor or serial number; and
at the same time, send copies of the petition by registered or certified mail to the owner and any known secured party.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: The petition for forfeiture shall contain:
the name of the registered owners of the vehicle;
the name of any secured party whose interest appears among the records maintained by the Clerk of the Circuit Court for Baltimore City;
a statement of the facts and circumstances surrounding the seizure of the vehicle;
a statement of the specific grounds for forfeiture; and
a request that the vehicle be forfeited to the City.
Within 7 days of the petition's filing, the Solicitor shall publish notice of the seizure and forfeiture proceeding in 1 or more newspapers of general circulation in the City.
The notice shall:
state the substance and object of the forfeiture petition; and
state that any person claiming an interest in the seized vehicle must file a defense to the petition within 15 days of the date of the notice.

para.heading: When to be made.
para.text: Any defense to the petition must be filed within 15 days after publication of the notice.
All defenses to a petition for forfeiture must be made by answer.
The answer must:
comply with the Maryland Rules of Procedure as to form and contents;
be divided into numbered paragraphs, each containing a separate and distinctive averment; and

respond to each material allegation contained in the petition, specifically admitting, denying, or explaining the facts alleged, unless the respondent is without knowledge or an admission or explanation would tend to incriminate the respondent, in either of which events the respondent must so state and that statement will operate as a denial.
Every allegation in the petition that is not denied in the answer is considered admitted, except as to persons unknown.
New or affirmative matter alleged in the answer is considered denied or avoided by the petitioner without the need of any replication, unless the court orders otherwise.
If the court determines that the vehicle should be forfeited, the court shall order the vehicle forfeited to the City.

If, however, the court determines that the vehicle is subject to a bona fide recorded security interest created without the knowledge that the vehicle was being or was to be used in violation of this subtitle, the court shall order that the vehicle be released within 5 days to the secured party of record.

para.heading: Disposition of vehicle subject to security interest.

para.text: The secured party:
shall sell the vehicle in a commercially reasonable manner; and
may not sell the vehicle to the owner or other person from whom it was seized.
The proceeds of the sale shall be applied as follows:
to the court costs of the forfeiture proceedings;
to the balance due to the secured party, including all reasonable costs incident to the sale;
to payment of all other expenses of the proceedings for forfeiture, including expenses of seizure, maintenance, or custody; and
to the general funds of the City.

para.heading: Disposition of forfeited vehicle.
para.text: A vehicle that has been ordered forfeited to the City may be:
sold as provided in City Code Article 31, Subtitle 31, Part 5;
transferred to a charitable organization for export abroad, as provided in City Code Article 31, § 31-58(c); or
destroyed.

section.heading: Order of release.
section.text: If, after a full hearing, the court determines that the vehicle should not be forfeited, the court shall order the vehicle released.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 for each offense or to imprisonment for not more than 90 days, or both fine and imprisonment, for each offense.

section.heading: Prohibited placement.
section.text: A person may not install an outdoor telephone:

para.text: in any public right-of-way without a minor privilege permit issued by or under the authority of the Board of Estimates; or
on any other public or private property without:
approval of the owner of the property; and
all permits required by the Public Service Commission.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Methods not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine of $1,000 for each offense, in addition to costs for removal.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues constitutes a separate offense.

section.heading: Commissioner authorized to issue.
section.text: The Police Commissioner of Baltimore City is authorized to issue personal press identification cards and press vehicle identification cards to any employee of a newspaper, news gathering agency, news photography agency, motion picture newsreel agency, radio broadcasting company, or television company operating in Baltimore City who is designated by his employer to gather information or pictures for distribution or broadcast to the general public as news.

section.heading: Applications.
section.text: Application for such identification cards shall be made by the individual employee, with appropriate verification of his employment responsibilities and duties, to the Police Commissioner on forms to be designated by the Police Commissioner.

para.heading: Issuance; revocation.
para.text: Upon approval of personal press identification card applications or press vehicle identification card applications, the Police Commissioner of Baltimore City may issue personal press identification cards and/or press vehicle identification cards to qualified applicants, which cards shall be subject to revocation at sound discretion of the Police Commissioner.

para.heading: Term.
para.text: The personal press identification cards and press vehicle identification cards shall not be issued for a period longer than 1 year.

para.heading: Renewal.
para.text: Qualified persons may be granted renewal personal press identification cards and/or press vehicle identification cards upon application.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: The Police Commissioner of Baltimore City is authorized to promulgate and issue rules and regulations concerning:

para.text: application procedures; and
temporary emergency parking and standing privileges and emergency area admittance privileges for holders of personal press identification cards and/or press vehicle identification cards.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct; penalties.
section.text: Any person who shall:

para.text: obtain or attempt to obtain either a personal press identification card or a press vehicle identification card contrary to the requirements of this subtitle;
duplicate, attempt to duplicate, counterfeit, or attempt to counterfeit, a personal press identification card and/or press vehicle identification card;
fail to surrender to the Police Commissioner any personal press identification card or press vehicle identification card within 3 days after notice of revocation of such card; or
fraudulently display such a card or display it contrary to the rules and regulations promulgated by the Police Commissioner pursuant to this subtitle,
shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than $5 nor more than $100, in the discretion of the court.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Assignation.
para.text: "Assignation" means an appointment or engagement for prostitution or any act in furtherance of the appointment or engagement.

para.heading: Commissioner.
para.text: "Commissioner" means the Police Commissioner of Baltimore City or the Commissioner's designee.

para.heading: Controlled dangerous substance.
para.text: "Controlled dangerous substance" means a substance listed in Schedule I or Schedule II under State Criminal Law Article § 5-402 or § 5-403.

para.heading: Controlled paraphernalia.
para.text: "Controlled paraphernalia" has the meaning stated in State Criminal Law Article § 5-101.

para.heading: Crime of violence.
para.text: "Crime of violence" has the meaning stated in State Criminal Law Article § 14-101.

para.heading: Operator.
para.text: "Operator" means any person who has charge, care, or control of a premises or structure.

para.heading: Owner.
para.text: "Owner" means the person in whose name a premises is recorded in the Land Records of Baltimore City.

para.heading: Premises.
para.text: "Premises" means all or any part of any land, building, or other structure.

para.heading: Prostitution.
para.text: "Prostitution" means the performance of a sexual act, sexual contact, or vaginal intercourse, as these terms are defined in State Criminal Law Article § 3-301, for hire.
"Public nuisance" means any premises that, on 2 or more separate occasions within a 24-month period, were used:
for prostitution, lewdness, or assignation;
for illegal adult entertainment;
by persons who assemble for the specific purpose of illegally administering a controlled dangerous substance;
for the illegal manufacture or distribution of:
a controlled dangerous substance; or
controlled paraphernalia;

for the illegal storage or concealment of a controlled dangerous substance or controlled paraphernalia in sufficient quantity to reasonably indicate under all the circumstances an intent to manufacture, distribute, or dispense:
a controlled dangerous substance; or
controlled paraphernalia;
for gambling;
for storage or possession of stolen property;
for storage or possession of unregistered firearms;
for furtherance of a crime of violence;
by persons who engage in a crime of violence on or near the premises; or
for criminal gang offenses prohibited under State Criminal Law Article 9, Subtitle 8.

Two reports by police officers, written in the regular course of business, of a premises' having been used for activities described in paragraph (1) of this subsection are prima facie evidence that the premises are a public nuisance.

para.heading: Commissioner's basic authority.
para.text: On determining that a public nuisance exists, the Commissioner may:
order the discontinuance of the public nuisance in the premises where the public nuisance exists; or
order the closing of the premises to the extent necessary to abate the nuisance.

Except as specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection, if the premises consists entirely of residential units or mixed residential and other use units, and the public nuisance has occurred solely within 1 or more residential units, abatement authority is restricted to the residential units in which the public nuisance has occurred, and does not extend to any other unit in the premises.
The restrictions of paragraph (1) of this subsection do not apply to a public nuisance occurring in any:
motel;
hotel; or
rooming house or rooming unit, as those terms are defined in the Zoning Code of Baltimore City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Before issuing an order under this subtitle, the Commissioner shall give notice and an opportunity for a hearing to the owner and any operator of the premises and to any commercial tenant of the premises.

para.heading: Contents of notice.
para.text: The notice shall state:
the date, place, and time of the hearing;
the right of the persons receiving the notice to be heard and to be represented at the hearing; and
the possible consequences of failure to appear, including the possible issuance of a default order directing the premises to be closed.
The notice shall be given by personal service or by certified or registered mail to the owner, operator, and commercial tenant, as their names and addresses:
are recorded in the Land Records of Baltimore City;
appear in the registration statement filed under City Code Article 13, Subtitle 4 {"Registration of Non-Owner-Occupied Dwellings, etc."}; or
are otherwise known or readily ascertainable.
In addition, the notice shall be posted on the premises.

para.heading: Proof of knowledge not required.
para.text: The Commissioner may order appropriate relief under § 43-3 of this subtitle without proof that an owner, operator, or tenant knew of the existence of the public nuisance.

para.heading: Discontinuance not a bar to relief.
para.text: Evidence that the nuisance has been discontinued at the time notice was provided or at the time of the hearing does not bar the Commissioner from imposing appropriate relief under § 43-3 of this subtitle.

para.heading: Issuance of order or finding.
para.text: Following the hearing procedure, the Commissioner shall:
on determining that a public nuisance exists, issue a written order in accordance with § 43-3 of this subtitle; or
on determining that a public nuisance does not exist, issue a written finding to that effect.

para.heading: Posting and notice of order.
para.text: Following the hearing procedure, an order issued under this subtitle shall be posted on the premises and notice of the order shall be given to the persons and in the manner set forth in § 43-4 of this subtitle.
After the order has been posted, as set forth in subsection (b) of this section, the order may be enforced on written directive of the Commissioner.
A closing shall be for the period that the Commissioner reasonably may direct, but in no event may the closing be for longer than 1 year.

para.heading: Nature of closing.
para.text: A closing directed by the Commissioner under this subtitle is not an act of possession, ownership, or control by the City of Baltimore.
The Commissioner may modify or rescind an order issued under this subtitle:
an owner or tenant affected by the order submits to the Commissioner a written request for modification or rescission; and
a hearing is held on the request.

An owner or tenant submitting a request under this subsection shall attach to the request any documents or other evidence that the owner or tenant wishes the Commissioner to consider in ruling on the request.
The Commissioner may grant the request if the Commissioner determines that the nuisance has been abated.

para.heading: Commissioner to adopt.
para.text: The Commissioner shall adopt rules, regulations, and hearing procedures as necessary or proper to carry out this subtitle.

para.heading: Filing with Legislative Reference.
para.text: A copy of all rules, regulations, and procedures must be filed with the Department of Legislative Reference before they take effect.

para.heading: Judicial review.
para.text: Any person aggrieved by any act of the Commissioner taken under this subtitle may seek judicial review of that act by petition to the Circuit Court for Baltimore City in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: Appellate review.
para.text: A party to the judicial review may appeal the court's final judgment to the Court of Special Appeals in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: Destruction, etc., of posted order.
para.text: No person may destroy, remove, or deface an order posted by the Commissioner under this subtitle.

para.heading: Failure to obey order.
para.text: No person may:
intentionally disobey any proper order issued by the Commissioner under this subtitle; or
use or occupy or permit any other person to use or occupy any premises ordered closed under this subtitle.

para.heading: Liability for unauthorized occupancy.
para.text: If any person uses or occupies or permits any other person to use or occupy any premises ordered closed by the Commissioner:
the Commissioner may execute the terms of the order to close the premises; and
the person is liable for all costs incurred by the Commissioner in executing the terms of the order to close the premises.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates a provision of § 43-11 is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to the following penalties:
for a violation of § 43-11(a) {"Prohibited conduct: Destruction, etc., of posted order"}, the offender is subject to a fine of not more than $500; and

for a violation of § 43-11(b) {"Prohibited conduct: Failure to obey order"}, the offender is subject to a fine of not more than $500 or to imprisonment for not more than 90 days or to both fine and imprisonment.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day a violation continues is a separate offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Commissioner.
para.text: "Commissioner" means the Police Commissioner of Baltimore City or the Commissioner's designee.

"Neighborhood nuisance" means any premises where, on 2 or more separate occasions within a 6-month period before the start of a proceeding under this subtitle, an owner or tenant of the premises engaged in acts or created or maintained conditions that:
significantly affected neighboring residents by being disorderly in manner; or
disturbed the peace of neighboring residents by:
making an unreasonably loud noise ; or
the unreasonable use of profanity, cursing, or swearing.

The 2nd report by a police officer, written in the regular course of business, of behavior or action of the type described in paragraph (1) of this subsection is prima facie evidence that a neighborhood nuisance has occurred.

para.heading: Operator.
para.text: "Operator" means any person who has charge, care, or control of a premises or structure.

para.heading: Owner.
para.text: "Owner" means the person in whose name a premises is recorded in the Land Records of Baltimore City.

para.heading: Premises.
para.text: "Premises" means all or any part of any land, building, or other structure.
"Tenant" means a lessee or any person occupying property, whether or not a party to a lease.
"Tenant" includes a lessee or a person occupying a mobile home, whether or not a party to a lease.

para.heading: Commissioner's authority.
para.text: On determining that a neighborhood nuisance exists, the Commissioner may:
order the discontinuance of the neighborhood nuisance in the premises where the nuisance exists; or
order the closing of the premises to the extent necessary to abate the nuisance.

Except as specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection, if the premises consists entirely of residential units or mixed residential and other use units, and the neighborhood nuisance has occurred solely within 1 or more residential units, abatement authority is restricted to the residential units in which the neighborhood nuisance has occurred, and does not extend to any other unit in the premises.
The restrictions of paragraph (1) of this subsection do not apply to a neighborhood nuisance occurring in any:
hotel;
motel; or
rooming house or rooming unit, as those terms are defined in the Zoning Code of Baltimore City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Before the Commissioner issues an order under this subtitle, the Commissioner shall give notice and an opportunity for a hearing to the owner and to any operator and tenant of the premises.

para.heading: Contents of notice.
para.text: The notice shall state:
the date, place, and time of the hearing;
the right of the persons receiving the notice to be heard and to be represented at the hearing; and
the possible consequences of failure to appear, including but not limited to the issuance of a default order directing the premises to be closed to the extent necessary to abate the nuisance.
The notice shall be given by personal service or by certified or registered mail to the owner and to any operator or tenant of the premises, as their names and addresses:
are recorded in the Land Records of Baltimore City;
appear in the registration statement filed under City Code Article 13, Subtitle 4 {"Registration of Non-Owner-Occupied Dwellings, etc."}; or
are otherwise known or readily ascertainable.
In addition, the notice shall be posted on the premises.

para.heading: Issuance of order or finding.
para.text: Following the hearing procedure, the Commissioner shall:
on determining that a neighborhood nuisance exists, issue a written order in accordance with § 43A-2; or
on determining that a neighborhood nuisance does not exist, issue a written finding so stating.

para.heading: Posting and notice of order.
para.text: Following the hearing procedure, an order of the Commissioner issued under this subtitle shall be posted on the premises and notice of the order shall be given to those persons and in the manner set forth in § 43A-3 of this subtitle.
After the order has been posted, as set forth in § 43A-3 of this subtitle, the order may be enforced.
A closing shall be for the period that the Commissioner reasonably may direct, but in no event may the closing be for longer than 1 year.

para.heading: Nature of closing.
para.text: A closing directed by the Commissioner under this subtitle is not an act of possession, ownership, or control by the City of Baltimore.
The Commissioner may modify or rescind an order issued under this subtitle if:
an owner or tenant affected by the order submits a written request to the Commissioner asking for the order to be modified or rescinded; and
a hearing is held on the request.

An owner or tenant submitting a request under this subsection shall attach as an exhibit any documents or other evidence that the owner or tenant wishes the Commissioner to consider in ruling on the request.
The Commissioner may grant a request submitted under this subsection if the Commissioner determines that the nuisance has been abated.

para.heading: Commissioner to adopt.
para.text: The commissioner shall adopt rules, regulations, and hearing procedures as necessary or proper to carry out this subtitle.

para.heading: Filing with Legislative Reference.
para.text: A copy of all rules, regulations, and procedures must be filed with the Department of Legislative Reference before they take effect.

para.heading: Judicial review.
para.text: Any person aggrieved by any act of the Commissioner under this subtitle may seek judicial review of that decision by petition to the Circuit Court for Baltimore City in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: Appellate review.
para.text: A party to the judicial review may appeal the court's final judgment to the Court of Special Appeals in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: Destruction, etc., of posted order.
para.text: No person may destroy, remove, or deface an order posted by the Commissioner under this subtitle

para.heading: Failure to obey order.
para.text: No person may:
intentionally disobey any proper order issued by the Commissioner under this subtitle; or
use or occupy or permit any other person to use or occupy any premises ordered closed under this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates a provision of § 43A-7 is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to the following penalties:
for a violation of § 43A-7(a) {"Prohibited conduct: Destruction, etc., of posted order"}, the offender is subject to a fine of not more than $500; and

for a violation of § 43A-7(b) {"Prohibited conduct: Failure to obey order"}, the offender is subject to a fine of not more than $500 or to imprisonment for not more than 90 days or to both fine and imprisonment.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

container.heading: Neighborhood Nuisances and Unruly Social Events

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Neighborhood nuisance.
para.text: "Neighborhood nuisance" means any privately owned premises on or in which an owner, operator, tenant, or occupant of or the holder of any possessory interest in those premises:
acts in a disorderly manner that disturbs the public peace; or
creates or maintains conditions that let others act in a disorderly manner that disturbs the public peace.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Alcoholic beverage" has the meaning stated in State Code Article 2B, § 1-102.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Alcoholic beverage" includes any mixture of an alcoholic beverage with a non-alcoholic beverage.

para.heading: Family event.
para.text: "Family event" means a party or gathering where each underage person present is directly supervised by an adult family member who is 21 years old or over.

para.heading: Occupant.
para.text: "Occupant" means any person occupying a premises, whether or not a party to a lease.

para.heading: Operator.
para.text: "Operator" means any person who has charge, care, or control of all or any part of a premises.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Owner" means:
the person in whose name a premises is recorded in the Land Records of Baltimore City; and
any other person with a legal or equitable interest in a premises.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Owner" includes a person who has an interest as a receiver, trustee, guardian, personal representative, fiduciary, or representative of any kind.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Owner" does not include the holder of a tax sale certificate until a judgment foreclosing all rights of redemption has been entered.

para.heading: Person responsible.
para.text: "Person responsible", when used with reference to any premises, means the owner, operator, tenant, or occupant of or the holder of any possessory interest in those premises, whether alone or jointly with any other person.

para.heading: Premises.
para.text: "Premises" means all or any part of any land, building, or other structure.

para.heading: Tenant.
para.text: "Tenant" means any tenant or lessee, whether under a written or oral lease.

para.heading: Underage person.
para.text: "Underage person" means any individual who is under the age of 21.

para.heading: Unruly social event.
para.text: "Unruly social event" means a party or gathering of 2 or more individuals on or in any privately owned premises at which:
