alcoholic beverages are consumed by, furnished to, or possessed by any underage person in violation of law; or
the conduct creates a disturbance of the peaceful enjoyment by others of private or public property, including:
noise in excess of the levels set by City Code Health Article, Title 9 {"Noise Regulation"}, or other law;
obstruction of public rights-of-way by unruly crowds;
public drunkenness;
assaults, batteries, or other disorderly conduct that disturbs the public peace;
vandalism of public or private property;
littering; or
any other conduct that constitutes a threat to the public health, safety, or general welfare.

section.heading: Exemptions from subtitle.
section.text: The activities described in § 43B-1(o)(1) of this subtitle {underage consumption, possession, etc., of alcoholic beverages} do not apply to:

para.text: legally-protected religious activities; or
family events.

Every person responsible for any premises is required to maintain, manage, and supervise the premises and all persons on or in the premises in a manner so as not to violate the provisions of this subtitle.
A person responsible for any premises remains liable for a neighborhood nuisance or an unruly social event even if that person was not present during the nuisance activity or the social event.

para.heading: Owner or operator.
para.text: An owner or operator of the premises remains liable for violating this subtitle regardless of any contract or agreement with any third party regarding the premises.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subsection, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Juvenile.
para.text: "Juvenile" means any individual who is under the age of 18.

para.heading: Parent.
para.text: "Parent" means any natural parent, adoptive parent, step-parent, or foster parent.

para.heading: Joint liability.
para.text: If the person responsible for the premises on or in which a neighborhood nuisance or an unruly social event occurs is a juvenile, then the juvenile and the parents or legal guardians of the juvenile are jointly and severally liable for the civil penalties imposed by this subtitle.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct.
section.text: No person responsible for any premises may conduct, cause, permit, aid, or condone a neighborhood nuisance or any unruly social event on or in those premises.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of a civil citation, as authorized by City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a civil citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

A civil citation may be issued under this subtitle without proof that the cited owner, operator, tenant, occupant, or holder of a possessory interest knew of or participated in the neighborhood nuisance or unruly social event.
For a civil citation issued under this subtitle to the owner or operator of leased property, it is a defense to any fine imposed on the owner or operator that:
the owner or operator neither authorized, knew in advance of, nor participated in the neighborhood nuisance or unruly social event; and
the owner or operator provides proof:
that the owner or operator has regained possession of the leased property; or

that the owner or operator has filed court proceedings under State Real Property Article § 8-402.1 {"Breach of lease"} and City Public Local Laws § 9-14, as applicable, to regain possession of the leased property and that:
the court has entered a judgment in favor of the owner or operator; or

those court proceedings are still pending at the time the citation is being adjudicated, in which case the court adjudicating the citation may postpone its proceedings until the conclusion of the court proceedings to regain possession.

For purposes of court proceedings filed under paragraph (2)(ii)(B) of this subsection, it is the intent of the Mayor and City Council that a violation of this subtitle shall be construed as demonstrating a clear and imminent danger that the persons responsible or others involved will do serious harm to themselves or others, within the scope and meaning of State Real Property Article § 8-402.1(a)(1)(i)2.B.

section.heading: "Scavenging" defined.
section.text: "Scavenging" means removing recyclable materials from a designated recycling container or area without approval from the owner or operator of the recycling operation designated to recover and process the materials.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct.
section.text: It is unlawful for any person not authorized by the Director of Public Works to remove or cause to be removed, any materials separated for the purpose of recycling and set at curbside or other pick-up locations for collection by authorized collectors.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any person violating a provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not more than $500.

container.heading: Signs - On or Affecting Public Property

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: City.
para.text: "City" means the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore.

para.heading: Sign.
para.text: "Sign" includes any bill, poster, placard, handbill, flyer, painting, notice, advertisement, or other similar object or matter that contains printed or written matter in words, symbols, pictures, or any combination of them.

section.heading: Postings prohibited.
section.text: No person may post, place, or affix a sign:

para.text: on any building owned, leased, or controlled by the City;
on or within the confines of any public park, recreation area, or other landscaped grounds owned or operated by the City;
on any flagpole or tree owned by the City;

on any traffic-control sign or device, including but not limited to, stop lights and their standards, stop signs, yield signs, 1-way street signs, and any other sign or device that directs traffic or controls traffic signals, or on the supporting post of any traffic-control sign or device;
in any way that:
blocks a motorist's, cyclist's, or pedestrian's view of a traffic-control sign or device so as to create a hazard;
protrudes into a street or sidewalk so as to interfere with the safe passage of the public; or
otherwise poses a hazard to motorists, pedestrians, or cyclists;
on any other property owned, leased, or controlled by the City; or
on any pole, building or property that is owned, leased, or controlled by a public utility and located within or on any public street, alley, or other public property.

para.heading: From City property – by Department.
para.text: For any sign posted in violation of § 45-2(1) through (6) of this subtitle, the Department of Housing and Community Development may:
summarily remove the sign or make the appropriate referral to have the sign removed; or
send written notice to the person responsible, as described in § 45-5 of this subtitle, ordering that person to remove the sign within the time specified in the notice.
For any sign posted in violation of § 45-2(1) through (6) of this subtitle, any individual may:
summarily remove the sign; and
either:
discard the sign in an appropriate manner; or
submit the sign to the Department of Housing and Community Development for further enforcement proceedings.
A submission to the Department of Housing and Community Development for further enforcement proceedings:
must be accompanied by an affidavit, in the form and tenor required by the regulations adopted under § 45-4 of this subtitle, that describes the circumstances of the violation and removal; and
may designate a non-profit community or neighborhood association listed with the Department of Planning to share in any fines that might be collected in the matter.
An association so designated is entitled to receive 50% of any fine collected under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"} or Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: From public utility property.
para.text: For any sign posted in violation of § 45-2(7) of this subtitle:
the public utility may summarily remove the sign; or

the public utility or the Department of Housing and Community Development may send written notice to the person responsible, as described in § 45-5 of this subtitle, ordering that person to remove the sign within the time specified in the notice.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who posts a sign in violation of this subtitle and any other person responsible for the sign, as described in § 45-5 of this subtitle, is liable to the City or to the public utility, as the case may be, for the costs of:
removing the sign; and
repairing any damage caused by the placement or removal of the sign.

para.heading: Rules and regulations for City property.

para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Commissioner of Housing and Community Development shall adopt regulations to provide for the removal of signs illegally placed on City property.
The regulations shall include:
charges to be assessed for the costs of removing illegal signs and repairing damages;
rules, procedures, and forms to carry out § 45-3(b) {"Removal of illegal signs: From City property – by others"} of this subtitle; and
provisions that require the Director to report:
the name of the person or entity represented on the material removed;
the number of advertisements, notices, or other signs removed;
the location of the material; and
the type of structure from which the material was removed.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.text: In the case of a political campaign, a candidate for any office and the chairman and treasurer of any registered political committee is presumptively liable for the costs of sign removal imposed by § 45-4 of this subtitle, as well as for the civil and criminal penalties imposed by this subtitle, if the candidate or the committee was responsible for printing the sign. If the liability is contested, the burden of overcoming the presumption is on the contesting party.

A candidate for public office shall, at the time of filing with the Board of Supervisors of Elections for the candidacy, sign a written statement that acknowledges the candidate's responsibilities under this subtitle. Failure to sign the statement does not affect the liability of the candidate for the penalties and costs provided for in this subtitle.

para.heading: Other cases.
para.text: In all other cases, the person whose name, event, business, location, or merchandise is written on the sign is presumptively liable for the charges imposed by § 45-4 of this subtitle, as well as for the civil and criminal penalties imposed by this subtitle. The burden of overcoming the presumption is on the contesting party.
In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.
The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: Criminal penalties.
para.text: Any person who posts a sign in violation of this subtitle or who fails to comply with a notice to remove a sign posted in violation of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $500 for each sign.

para.heading: Aggressive soliciting.
para.text: "Aggressive soliciting" means soliciting which is accompanied by 1 or more of the following:

approaching, speaking to, or following a person in such a manner as would cause a reasonable person to fear bodily harm or the commission of a criminal act upon the person or upon property in the person's immediate possession;
in the course of soliciting, touching another person without that person's consent;
continuously soliciting from a person or following the person after the person has made a negative response;
intentionally blocking or interfering with the safe passage of a person or a vehicle by any means, including unreasonably causing a person to take evasive action to avoid physical contact;
using obscene or abusive language either during the course of soliciting or following a refusal; or
acting with the intent of intimidating another person into giving money or another thing of value.

para.heading: Place open to the general public.
para.text: "Place open to the general public" means sidewalks, streets, alleys, driveways, parking lots and garages, parks, plazas, buildings, doorways and entrances to buildings, the grounds enclosing buildings, or the mall and/or adjacent parking areas of any shopping center to which the general public is invited for business purposes.

"Soliciting" means any act by which 1 person requests an immediate donation of money or other thing of value from another or others in person, regardless of the solicitor's purpose or intended use of the money or other thing of value.
The solicitation may be oral, written, or by other means of communication.

section.heading: Findings and declarations.
section.text: The Mayor and City Council:

para.text: finds and declares that aggressive soliciting and soliciting in certain places and circumstances have a detrimental effect on the creation of a safe environment in the City of Baltimore; and

finds that restricting certain acts, without prohibiting soliciting, is a necessary exercise of the police, health, and welfare power in order to maintain the peace and good government of Baltimore City and to preserve and protect the rights of all citizens.

section.heading: Aggressive soliciting in public places prohibited.
section.text: It is unlawful for any person to engage in aggressive soliciting in any place open to the general public.

section.heading: Soliciting in certain ways and places prohibited.
section.text: It is unlawful for any person to engage in soliciting:

para.text: within 10 feet of any automatic teller machine (ATM);
in any public transportation vehicle or at any bus, train, light rail, or subway station or stop;
on private property or residential property, if the owner, tenant, or occupant has asked the person not to solicit on the property or has posted a sign on the property indicating no soliciting;
from any operator or occupant of a motor vehicle that is in traffic on a public street, whether in exchange for cleaning the vehicle's windows or otherwise; or
from any operator or occupant of a motor vehicle on a public street in exchange for blocking, occupying, or reserving a public parking space or directing the occupant to a public parking space.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, no person may engage in soliciting between sunset and sunrise.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: This section does not apply to soliciting that is done solely:
by passively standing or sitting with a sign or other indication that one is seeking donations; and
without addressing any oral or other solicitation to any specific person other than in response to an inquiry by that person.
This section may be enforced by issuance of a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.
A citation may be issued under this section only by a police officer.
No person may be imprisoned for a violation of this section, for failing to pay a fine imposed under this section, or for failing to appear in court.

annotation.text: Ord. 04-675, which added § 47-5 and amended the succeeding sections, provides

“[T]his Ordinance ... will remain effective until the repeal or abrogation of City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {“Civil Citations”}, as enacted by Ordinance 03-595; on the repeal or abrogation of that subtitle, with no further action by the Mayor and City Council, this Ordinance will be abrogated and of no further effect.”

section.heading: Other soliciting permitted.
section.text: "Soliciting" as defined in § 47-1(c) of this subtitle is lawful except only as specified in this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, any person who violates a provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof:
shall be fined not more than $100 or imprisoned for not more than 30 days, or both; or
if the person has been convicted of a violation of this subtitle within the previous year, the person shall be fined not more than $250 or imprisoned for not more than 90 days, or both.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: This section does not apply to any violation of § 47-5 {"Nighttime soliciting prohibited"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: "Missile" defined.
para.text: In this section, "missile" means any object capable of being thrown or used as a projectile, but does not include empty paper wrappers.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: This section does not apply to a member of a team or an official participating as a principal in a sporting event while engaged in the course of conduct required by that sporting event.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: It is unlawful for any person to toss, throw, fling, or project, or to cause the tossing, throwing, flinging, or projecting of any missile:
on or in the direction of any member of a team or official participating as a principal in a sporting event; or
on any playing field or arena during the course of a sporting event.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person who violates a provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for not more than 12 months or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: It is unlawful for any person to offer for sale or resale or to possess for sale or resale any Preakness Stakes ticket that:
is forged or counterfeit; or
is in any way printed or issued without the consent of the Maryland Jockey Club of Baltimore City, Inc.
Any person who violates a provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 for each offense.
Each ticket that is offered or possessed in violation of this section is a separate offense.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: It is unlawful for any person to operate an aircraft over or around the outer limits of M&T Bank Stadium or Oriole Park at Camden Yards for any advertising or commercial purposes.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person who violates a provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "The Star-Spangled Banner" shall not be played, sung or rendered in the City of Baltimore in any public place, or at any public entertainment, or in any theatre or moving picture hall, restaurant, or cafe, except as an entire and separate composition or number, without embellishments of national or other melodies.

para.heading: Use in medley prohibited.
para.text: Nor shall "The Star-Spangled Banner" or any part thereof or selection from the same be played as a part or selection of a medley of any kind.

section.heading: Use for dancing or exit march prohibited.
section.text: Nor shall "The Star-Spangled Banner" be played at or in any of the places mentioned for dancing or as an exit march.

section.heading: Performers, etc., to stand.
section.text: And whenever and wherever practicable, the musicians, performers, or other persons shall stand while playing, singing, or rendering "The Star-Spangled Banner".

section.heading: Proprietor responsible.
section.text: No owner, proprietor, or manager of any theatre, moving picture hall, or restaurant, cafe or other place in the City of Baltimore where the public gathers shall permit or allow anyone playing, singing, or performing therein to play, sing, or render "The Star-Spangled Banner" in violation of the provisions of this subtitle, and in the event of any such permission or allowance, such owner, proprietor, or manager, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to the penalties imposed by § 49-6 of this subtitle.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any person violating the provisions of this subtitle shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof before a Court of competent jurisdiction of this State, shall be fined not more than $100.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: Except as specifically provided in this section, no person may in any manner obstruct any street, lane, sidewalk, footway, or alley in the City or any of their gutters.

para.heading: Exception for deliveries, etc.
para.text: This section does not apply to someone in the immediate act of delivering items to or removing items from a place of business or a dwelling as long as the items do not us more space than ½ of the pavement.
In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this section may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.
The issuance of a citation to enforce this section does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.
Any person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction, is subject to the penalties specified in this subsection.
On a 1st conviction, the penalty for a violation of this section is a fine of not more than $250 for each offense.
On a 2nd or subsequent conviction, the penalty for a violation of this section is a fine of not more than $500 for each offense.

annotation.doc: City of Balt., Md., Rev. Ords. 1858-033

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: No person may place, set, or display any vegetables or fruit or any other goods, wares, or merchandise at a distance of more than 3 feet from the house or store from which they are being sold.
In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this section may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.
The issuance of an environmental citation to enforce this section does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.
Any person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction, is subject to the penalties specified in this section.
On a 1st conviction, the penalty for a violation of this section is a fine of not more than $50 for each offense.
On a 2nd or subsequent conviction, the penalty for a violation of this section is a fine of not more than $100 for each offense.

section.heading: Throwing bales, etc.; using slides, etc.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: It shall not be lawful for any person:
to throw any bale or bulky article from the 2nd or higher story door or window into the street; or

to use, or cause to be used, in or upon any street, lane, or alley, wharf, or place of public resort, any sliding board, skid, or other device or contrivance for the purpose of receiving or delivering merchandise, without having the same well secured, so as to prevent the same from slipping.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: Provided, that this section shall not be construed to extend to the removing of any merchandise or other article in case of danger by fire or other casualty.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: And every person who shall offend in manner aforesaid shall pay for every such offense the sum of $20.

section.heading: Removal of obstructions by City.
section.text: The Director of Transportation is authorized and empowered to remove or cause to be removed any obstruction to passage through a street, lane, or alley.

annotations.annotation: Ordinance 07-496 repealed former § 50-12, “Eviction chattels”, and enacted new City Code Article 13, Subtitle 8A, in its stead.
Ordinance 04-854 repealed former Part 3, “Street Sales Near Farmers’ Markets”, and rewrote City Code Article 15, Subtitle 17, to include similar provisions.

Ordinance 15-435 repealed former Part 4, dealing with the fires in streets, lanes, and alleys. The provisions of that part (virtually unchanged since their enactment in 1858) have been effectively superseded by the more extensive provisions of the International Fire Code Chapter 3 {“General Requirements”}, as adopted by Part VIII of the City’s Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article. See, e.g., FC § 303 {“Asphalt kettles”}, § 307 {“Open burning...”}, and § 308 {“Open flames”}.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: It is unlawful for any organization or persons to parade through the streets of the City without first obtaining a permit to do so from the Department of Transportation.

para.heading: Specifications.
para.text: The permit shall specify the streets through which, and the hours within which, the parade is to pass.

para.heading: Notice.
para.text: Before a permit is granted, the Department of Transportation shall make reasonable efforts to notify the local community and business groups, as listed in the Community Association Directory published by the Department of Planning, that might be affected by the proposed parade.

para.heading: Rules and regulations.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of Transportation may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this section.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, subject to a fine of not more than $500 or to imprisonment for not more than 60 days or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.
Ordinance 09-148 repealed this Part 7, in its entirety, and enacted a new section, Property Maintenance Code § 305.8, with similar requirements.

As introduced, Ordinance 09-149 (Council Bill 08-253) would have amended § 50-56 to add the solicitation of donations to its coverage. Accordingly, the bill also amended the name of this Part to “Soliciting Customers or Donations”. Before enactment, however, the proposed reference to donations was deleted from the section, but not from the Part’s title. In codifying the amended section, we have omitted the no-longer relevant title change.

section.heading: Obstructing passage prohibited.
section.text: It is unlawful for any person in or on any street or sidewalk or footways to obstruct passage along the street or sidewalk by catching hold of or soliciting persons or in any way interfering with their free passage, for the purpose of inducing or compelling them to buy any article or thing.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, § 50-56 of this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Method not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a civil citation to enforce § 50-56 of this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

section.heading: Criminal penalties.
section.text: Any person who violates a provision of § 50-56 of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $200 for each offense.

section.heading: Sand, ashes, etc., prohibited on streets.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: It shall be unlawful for any person or persons, or corporation, to deposit or scatter sand, ashes, or other matter on any part of the streets or alleys of the City of Baltimore, excepting sidewalks thereof, in time of ice or sleet.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: Provided, that nothing in this section shall be construed as to prevent street railway companies from placing sand on their rails at heavy grades.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person or persons, or corporation, violating the provisions of this section shall forfeit and pay a fine of $10 for each and every offense, to be recovered as other fines and forfeitures for the violation of City ordinances are recovered.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Park rule.
para.text: "Park rule" means any rule or regulation adopted by the Director of Recreation and Parks under the authority of Article VII, § 67(f) of the City Charter and subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

section.heading: Compliance with rules required.
section.text: No person may violate a park rule.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, a park rule may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"};
a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}; or
a prepayable criminal citation under City Code Article 19, Subtitle 71 {"Special Enforcement Officers"}.

para.heading: Methods not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce a park rule does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of a park rule is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 for each offense.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: It is unlawful for any person who engages and accepts transportation in a taxicab or other vehicle operated as a common carrier to wilfully refuse to pay the proper charges at the conclusion of the transportation.

para.heading: Special arrangements allowed.
para.text: This section does not prevent the owner or operator of the taxicab or other common carrier from arranging with the person who engaged and accepted transportation for subsequent payment of the charges due.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person who violates a provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of $250 for each offense.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit, offer to transport, or transport a passenger or passengers for hire in Baltimore City unless said person offering to transport shall be operating a vehicle duly authorized to perform taxicab services in Baltimore City under the authority of the Public Service Commission of Maryland.

para.heading: Scope of prohibition.
para.text: This section is intended to include as illegal:

the operation of a licensed taxicab in Baltimore City from a jurisdiction other than Baltimore City, unless such transportation is a fare or the continuation of a fare originating in said other jurisdiction; and
any use of a private vehicle to transport passengers for hire in performing taxicab services.

para.heading: Enforcement; penalties.
para.text: A police officer shall issue a citation to any violator of this section and said charge shall be deemed a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, said person shall be subject to a fine of not greater than $500 or to imprisonment for a period of not longer than 6 months, or to both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the Court.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct.
section.text: It is unlawful for any person to make use of telephone facilities or equipment:

para.text: for an anonymous call, if in a manner which may annoy, abuse, torment, harass, or embarrass one or more persons; or
for any request, suggestion, or proposal which, to the person receiving the call, is objectionably profane, obscene, vulgar, lewd, lascivious, or indecent.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: A violation of any one of the provisions of this section is a misdemeanor, subject upon conviction of a fine not greater than $500 or to imprisonment for a period not longer than 12 months, or to both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the Court.

para.text: Any performance is "obscene" if:
considered as a whole, its predominant appeal is to prurient, shameful, or morbid interest in nudity, sex, excretion, sadism, or masochism;
it goes substantially beyond customary limits of candor in describing or representing such matters; and
it is utterly without redeeming social value.

Predominant appeal shall be judged with reference to ordinary adults unless it appears from the character of the circumstances of its dissemination to be designed for children or other specially susceptible audiences.

para.heading: Performance.
para.text: "Performance" means any play, dance, or other exhibition performed or displayed before an audience.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct; penalty.
para.text: Every person who shall within the City of Baltimore knowingly act, exhibit, show, or perform in, or cause to be acted, exhibited, shown, or performed, or be in any manner concerned in or permits to be conducted at any premises or place under his control, the acting, exhibition, showing, or performance of any obscene play, farce, opera, public exhibition, show, or entertainment or performance whatsoever or participate in any part of any such obscene play, farce, opera, public exhibition, show, entertainment, or performance whatsoever, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor subject to a penalty for each offense of a fine not over $100.

annotation.doc: City of Balt., Md., Rev. Ords. 1858-037

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: No agent, owner, or lessee of any house of public amusement, or any agent, owner, or lessee of any show, circus, or public exhibition of any kind whatsoever, shall suffer or permit any person whomsoever to do or perform those acts in which feats of strength and skill are exhibited by the performer from apparatus suspended at an extraordinary elevation above the stage, without first providing a network of such character and materials as in the event of any miscalculation on the part of the performer or performers, will be the means of saving him, her or them from accident or injury.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any agent, owner, or lessee of any house of public amusement, or any agent, owner, or lessee of any show, circus, or public exhibition of any kind whatsoever, offending against the provisions of this section shall forfeit and pay a fine of $50 for every time such offense may be committed in his, her, or their house or place of public amusement, to be recovered as other fines are recoverable.

annotations.annotation: Ordinance 13-157 repealed this Article 19, Subtitle 55 {“Ticket Sales”} and Article 15, Subtitle 21 {“Ticket Agencies”}, replacing their provisions with a new Article 2, Subtitle 16 {“Ticket Sales”}. Ord. 13-157 became effective September 18, 2013.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: It is unlawful for any person to wilfully and maliciously destroy, injure, deface, molest, or spray or splash with paint, lacquer, or similar substance any theatre, place of worship, public building, or any real or personal property of another.

Any person who violates the provisions of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, is subject to a fine of not less than $100 and not more than $1,000, or imprisonment in jail not exceeding 90 days, or to both fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court.

In addition to a fine or imprisonment, or both, or in lieu of a fine or imprisonment or both, a judge may sentence a person convicted under this section to perform community service, which may include the cleaning of any property defaced by such vandalism.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: Any person who wilfully or maliciously:
defaces or molests the real or personal property or premises of a church, religious organization, religious institution, parsonage, or church home;

inscribes or places upon, adjacent, or near to any such property or premises, a mark, letter, or symbol for the purpose of inciting or causing the hatred, criticism, ridicule, disaffection, or disturbance of a religious group, sect, or congregation, or of any member thereof; or
desecrates, mutilates, or disfigures any such property or premises,
is guilty of a misdemeanor.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Upon conviction thereof, he is subject to a fine not to exceed $500 or to imprisonment for a period not to exceed 12 months or to both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: No person may wilfully break, defile, remove, deface, carry away, or otherwise damage or injure any street lighting or other public utility structure, or any equipment, part, or appurtenance of a public utility structure.

para.heading: Liability.
para.text: Any person who violates this section is, in addition to any other applicable penalty, liable to the City or other owner of the structure, equipment, etc., for the expense of repairing, cleaning, and restoring it.

Any person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for not more than 12 months or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.
Each structure damaged or injured under this section is a separate offense.

It shall be unlawful for any person to carry in any vehicles or about his person, except in his place of abode, fixed place of business, target range, gun show, historic reenactment, or civic event held on a National Monument or a Historic Shrine or parade for which a permit has been obtained, any rifle, shotgun or other firearm the barrel of which is over 14 inches in length.
Provided that this subsection shall not apply to:
marshals, sheriffs, prison or jail wardens, or their deputies while in the performance of their official duty;
policemen or other law enforcement officers;
members of the armed forces of the United States or of the National Guard or organized reserves when on duty;

holders of special police commissions issued under Title 4, Subtitle 9, of Article 41 of the Maryland Code, while actually on duty on the property for which the commission was issued or while traveling to or from such duty;

uniformed security guards, special railway police, and watchmen who have been cleared for such employment by the appropriate governmental agency, while in the course of their employment or while traveling to or from the place of employment;

guards in the employ of a bank, savings and loan association, building and loan association, or express or armored car agency, while in the course of their employment or while traveling to or from the place of employment;
manufacture, transportation, or sale of weapons to persons authorized under law to possess such under the laws of the United States;
transportation of firearms unloaded and carried in an enclosed case or rack designed for that purpose;
antique firearms, meaning:
any firearm (including any firearm with a matchlock, flintlock, percussion cap, or similar type of ignition system) manufactured in or before 1898; and
any replica of any firearm described in subitem (A) if such replica:
is not designed or redesigned for using rimfire or conventional centerfire fixed ammunition; or
uses rimfire or conventional centerfire fixed ammunition which is no longer manufactured in the United States and which is not readily available in the ordinary channels of commercial trade.

para.heading: Carrying prohibited — intent to commit crime.
para.text: It shall be unlawful for any person to carry in any about his person any rifle, shotgun, or other firearms the barrel of which is over 14 inches in length with the intent to use the rifle, shotgun, or other firearm in the commission of a crime against the person or property of another.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any violation of the provisions of this section shall be deemed a misdemeanor, subject upon conviction to a fine of not more than $500 or to imprisonment for not longer than 60 days or to both fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the Court.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct; penalties.
para.text: If any person shall fire or discharge any gun, pistol, or firearm within the City, unless it be on some occasion of military parade, and then by order of some officer having the command, every such person for every such offense shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, pay a fine not to exceed $1,000, or be imprisoned for a term not to exceed 1 year, or both.

para.heading: Discharge on vessel.
para.text: If any gun, pistol, or firearm shall be discharged from on board any vessel within the harbor of Baltimore, the captain of the vessel, as well as the offender, shall be liable to the said penalty.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: Nothing in this section shall be held to apply to or prohibit the discharge or firing of any such firearms on permanently located, properly posted and bona fide target ranges, the location of which has been fled with the Police Department of Baltimore City.

annotation.doc: City of Balt., Md., Rev. Ords. 1858-033

para.heading: "Handgun" defined.
para.text: In this section, "handgun" means a firearm, as defined in State Public Safety Article § 5-101(h), the barrel of which is 14 inches or under in length.

para.heading: Carrying prohibited.
para.text: A person may not:
wear, carry, or knowingly transport a handgun, whether concealed or open, on or about the person within 100 yards of, or in, a:
park;
church;
school;
public building; or
other place of public assembly;
wear, carry, or knowingly transport a handgun, whether concealed or open, in a vehicle traveling on a road within 100 yards of a:
park;
church;
school;
public building; or
other place of public assembly; or
wear, carry, or knowingly transport a handgun in connection with the commission of a crime against a person or property, within 100 yards of, or in, a:
park;
church;
school;
public building; or
other place of public assembly.

para.heading: Permissible inference.
para.text: The finder of fact may infer that a person who transports a handgun in violation of this section transports the handgun knowingly.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: This section does not prohibit the wearing, carrying, or transporting of a handgun by a person covered by an exception in State Criminal Law Article § 4-203(b).
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to the following penalties for each offense:
if the handgun was worn, carried, or transported in connection with the commission of a crime against a person or property, mandatory imprisonment for 1 year and a mandatory fine of $1,000;

if the person has a previous conviction for a violation of this section or {of} State Criminal Law Article § 4-203 {"Wearing, carrying, or transporting handgun"}, mandatory imprisonment for 1 year and a mandatory fine of $1,000; or
if neither item (i) nor item (ii) of this paragraph apply, a fine of not more than $1,000 or imprisonment for not longer than 12 months or both fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the Court.
The court may not impose less than, or suspend any part of, any mandatory sentence provided in paragraph (1) of this subsection.
A person who violates this section is not eligible for a probation before judgment.
A person who violates this section is not eligible for parole.
Each violation of this section is a separate offense.
In general.
In this Part, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Ammunition.
para.text: "Ammunition" means any cartridge, shell, or other device that contains explosive or incendiary material and is designed or intended for use in any firearm.

para.heading: Child safety lock.
para.text: "Child safety lock" means:
a device that, when locked in place, prevents the trigger from being moved and can itself be removed only by using a key or combination; or
any other device that:
when locked in place, otherwise renders the firearm inoperable and can itself be removed only by using a key or combination; and
has been approved for this purpose by the Police Commissioner.

para.heading: Firearm.
para.text: "Firearm" means any pistol, revolver, rifle, shotgun, short-barreled rifle, short-barreled shotgun, or other firearm, except an inoperable antique firearm.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a person may not leave a loaded firearm, or an unloaded firearm that is in close proximity to ammunition, in any location where the person knows or reasonably should know that an unsupervised minor might gain access to the firearm.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: Subsection (a) of this section does not apply if:
the minor's access to the firearm is supervised by a person 21 years old or older;
the firearm is in a locked gun cabinet or similar locked location;
the firearm is secured with a child safety lock;
the minor obtained access to the firearm as the result of an unlawful entry to the premises; or
the firearm is in the possession or control of a law enforcement officer while the officer is engaged in official duties.
A licensed firearm dealer may not sell, lease, or otherwise transfer a firearm without an accompanying child safety lock suitable for that firearm.
The dealer must provide the child safety lock to the recipient of the firearm when transferring the firearm. The dealer may charge for the child safety lock.
A licensed firearm dealer who sells, leases, or otherwise transfers a firearm must post conspicuously in the dealer's place of business:
a notice of the prohibition in § 59-12 of this Part against leaving a firearm where an unsupervised minor can obtain access to it; and
a notice of the prohibition in subsection (a) of this section against the transfer of a firearm without an accompanying child safety lock.

If the transaction occurs outside the dealer's place of business, or if the dealer does not maintain a place of business in a commercial establishment, the dealer must provide the required notices in writing when transferring the firearm.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: The Police Commissioner may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this Part, including but not limited to rules or regulations governing the wording, size, and placement of the notices required by this Part.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this Part or of a rule or regulation adopted under this Part is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of $1,000 or to imprisonment for 1 year or both.

section.heading: "Firearm" defined.
section.text: In this Part 2A, "firearm" includes any pistol, revolver, rifle, shotgun, short-barreled rifle, short-barreled shotgun, or other firearm.

section.heading: Reporting required.
section.text: If a firearm is lost or stolen, the person who owned the firearm shall report the theft or loss to the Baltimore Police Department. The report shall be made within 48 hours after the theft or loss is first discovered.

section.heading: Entry to NCIC Database.
section.text: On receipt of a report of a stolen or lost firearm, the Baltimore Police Department shall enter into the National Crime Information Center Database the following information, to the extent known:

para.text: the firearm's caliber, make, model, manufacturer, and serial number; and
any other distinguishing number or identification mark on the firearm.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, § 59-18 of this Part 2A may be enforced by issuance of a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a civil citation to enforce § 59-18 of this Part 2A does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

section.heading: Criminal penalties.
section.text: Any person who violates § 59-18 of this Part 2A is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to the following penalties:

para.text: for a 1st offense, a fine of not more than $500; and
for any subsequent offense, a fine of not more than $750 or imprisonment for not more than 90 days or both fine and imprisonment.

para.heading: Sale prohibited.
para.text: It shall be unlawful for any person to sell any metal knuckles, sling shot, slung shot, sand club, or black jack in the City of Baltimore.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: Except that black jacks may be sold to:
duly qualified police officers; or
any person having a permit from the Police Commissioner to permit him to make such purchase or purchases.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than $500 or be imprisoned for not more than 1 year, or both, in the discretion of the court.

section.heading: Switchblade knives – Possession or sale, etc.

para.heading: Prohibited possession or sale, etc.
para.text: No person may sell, carry, or possess any knife with an automatic spring or other device for opening or closing the blade, commonly known as a switchblade knife.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for not more than 12 months or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

section.heading: Dangerous knives – Transfer, etc.; Commercial displays.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Dangerous knife.
para.text: "Dangerous knife" means any:
Bowie knife;
dirk knife;
gravity knife;
shooting knife, as described in State Criminal Law Article § 4-105;
star knife, as defined in State Criminal Law Article § 4-101;
straight razor;
switchblade knife, as described in § 59-22 of this subtitle or in State Criminal Law Article § 4-105; or
any knife with a blade that is longer than 3 inches.

para.heading: Prohibited transfer, etc., to individuals under 21.
para.text: No person may sell, give, or otherwise transfer a dangerous knife to, or permit the use or possession of a dangerous knife by, any individual that the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe is under the age of 21.

para.heading: Placement in windows or glass display cases prohibited.

para.text: Except as provided in part (ii) of this paragraph, no person may place a dangerous knife in an exterior window or glass display case of a commercial establishment that offers knives for sale.
The display of a dangerous knife in a glass display case is permitted in a commercial establishment that sells primarily sporting goods.

para.heading: Placement in establishments open to individuals under 21.
para.text: In any commercial establishment open to individuals under the age of 21, a dangerous knife available for sale must be placed behind a sales counter and be inaccessible to individuals under the age of 21.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for not more than 12 months or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: As used in this section, the following words have the meanings indicated unless their context clearly indicates otherwise.

para.heading: Mini-crossbow; pistol-crossbow.
para.text: "Mini-crossbow" or "pistol-crossbow" means a weapon:
consisting of a bow fixed across a stock or pistol-shaped device having a groove or barrel for the arrow or similar missile and a mechanism for holding and releasing the string;
used for shooting arrows or similar missiles; and
having an overall length of less than 18 inches.

para.heading: Possession or sale, etc., prohibited.
para.text: A person shall not wear, carry, possess, sell, purchase, transfer, give, or trade a mini-crossbow or pistol-crossbow in the City of Baltimore.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: The provisions of this section shall not apply to:
a sworn police officer;
a museum or similar institution for historical display purposes; or
a demonstration by an organization at a public event approved by the Police Commissioner of Baltimore City.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person who violates a provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine of not more than $500 or imprisonment for not more than 90 days or both fine and imprisonment.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: "Gas- or air-pellet gun".
para.text: "Gas- or air-pellet gun" means any gun or other device, by whatever name or description known, that is designed to discharge or can readily be converted to discharge a pellet or other object by the expansion of gas or air.

para.heading: Paintball gun.
para.text: "Paintball" means any gun or other device, including a gas- or air- pellet gun, that is used or designed or intended to be used to discharge a paintball or other object designed or intended to mark a target with pigmentation.

para.heading: Giving, etc., to minor prohibited.
para.text: No person may sell, give away, or otherwise transfer a gas- or air-pellet gun or paintball gun to, or permit the use or possession of a gas- or air-pellet gun or paintball gun by, any individual whom that person knows or has reasonable cause to believe is a minor.

para.heading: Possess, discharge, or use.
para.text: No person may possess, discharge or use any gas- or air- pellet gun or paintball gun in Baltimore City except:
if the gun is kept within his or her domicile or is used by him or her exclusively for the purpose of teaching the use and care of firearms at a properly constructed indoor or outdoor range;
on a properly constructed target range or recreational paintball facility;

on private grounds or residence under circumstances in which the gun is operated so as to not endanger person or property and in a manner that prevents the projectile from traversing any grounds or space outside of the private grounds or residence; or
if the gun is being transported in a motor vehicle for any lawful purpose and is not being carried on a person.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for not more than 12 months or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: Possession or sale, etc., prohibited.
para.text: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to sell, offer for sale by any means whatsoever, give away, lend, rent, or otherwise transfer or attempt to transfer, or to own, possess, use, handle, or permit the use of, any dart gun, blow gun, or other device by whatever name or description known, which is discharged or operated by introducing air or any type of gas into any part of a hollow tube or shaft and thereby causing to be ejected therefrom any dart, needle, arrow, pin, pellet, or any other object which is capable of inflicting any injury, damage, or harm to or upon any person, animal, or bird.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prevent the use of any such device for the treatment, capture, or destruction of animals when any such use takes place under the supervision of a veterinarian, policeman, or any other person who is regularly engaged or employed in the handling, training, treatment, or maintenance of animals.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any violation of the provisions of this section shall be deemed to be a misdemeanor, subject upon conviction to a fine of not more than $500 or to imprisonment for not longer than 60 days or to both fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the Court.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
"Electronic control device".
"Electronic control device" means a portable device designed as a weapon capable of injuring, immobilizing, or inflicting pain on an individual by the discharge of electrical current.
"Adjudicated as a mental defective".

"Adjudicated as a mental defective" means a determination by a court, board, commission, or other lawful authority, that, as a result of marked subnormal intelligence, mental illness, incompetency, condition, or disease, a person:
is a danger to themselves or to others; or
lacks the mental capacity to contract or manage his or her own affairs.
"Mental disorder".
"Mental disorder" means a behavioral or emotional illness that results from a psychiatric disorder.

"Mental disorder" includes a mental illness that so substantially impairs the mental or emotional functioning of an individual as to make care or treatment necessary or advisable for the welfare of the individual or for the safety of the person or property of another.
"Protective order".
"Protective order" means a temporary or final protective order entered under the authority of Maryland Code, Family Law Article, §§ 4-505 and 4-506.

para.heading: Possession or sale, etc., prohibited.
para.text: In addition to all State law prohibitions and penalties on the sales of electronic control devices, including no sales to minors, no sales to those convicted of certain crimes, and no sales without background checks, it is unlawful in the City:
for any person to possess an electronic control device in a:
public school;
State public building; or
City public building;
for any person to sell or ship an electronic control device to any other person knowing or having reasonable cause to believe that the other person has been:
adjudicated as a mental defective; or
committed to any mental institution;
for any person to possess an electronic control device if the person suffers from a mental disorder and has a history of violent behavior against themselves or another; and
for any person subject to a protective order to possess an electronic control device for the duration of the protective order.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: Nothing in this section shall be held to apply to any member of the Baltimore City Police Department or any other law enforcement officer while in the performance of his or her official duty.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any violation of the provisions of this section shall be deemed to be a misdemeanor, subject upon conviction to a fine of not more than $1,00 or to imprisonment for not longer than 12 months or to both fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the Court.

para.heading: "Stench bomb" defined.
para.text: A stench bomb is herein defined as any liquid, gaseous, or solid substance or matter of any kind which is intended to be thrown, dropped, poured, deposited, or discharged for the purpose of producing a noxious, nauseating, sickening, irritating, or offensive odor.

para.heading: Possession, sale, use, etc., prohibited.
para.text: It is unlawful for any person to:
sell, barter, or trade a stench bomb;
manufacture, make, or prepare a stench bomb;
throw, drop, pour, deposit, or discharge a stench bomb; or
aid or abet another in throwing, dropping, pouring, depositing, or discharging a stench bomb.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: Nothing in the above provisions shall apply to:
regularly appointed police officers acting in line of duty; nor
proprietors of business places who may keep or use certain acid diffusing bombs solely for the purpose of repelling robbers, thieves, or other law violators.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, is subject to a fine of not less than $5 and not more than $500 at the discretion of the court.

para.heading: Possession, use, etc., by minors prohibited.
para.text: It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to carry, use, or discharge any weapon or device commonly known as a tear gas gun, or any tear gas device.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than $100 for each such violation.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Court or Police Magistrate who convicts any person of any criminal offense shall declare as forfeited and confiscated any gun, pistol, firearm, switch-blade knife, or other dangerous weapon which was in the possession of the person at the time of committing the offense and which either was used or held for possible use in connection with the offense.

para.heading: Disposition.
para.text: The said weapon shall be turned over to the Police Department of Baltimore City for disposal and shall not be treated or considered as the property of the person so convicted.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Convicted.
para.text: "Convicted" means:
having been found guilty of a gun offense by a jury or judicial officer;
the acceptance of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere for a gun offense;
having been granted a probation before judgment after a finding of guilt for a gun offense, if the court orders compliance with this subtitle as a condition of probation; or
having been found not criminally responsible for a gun offense.

para.heading: Correctional facility.
para.text: "Correctional facility" means a facility that is operated for the purpose of detaining or confining adults who are charged with or found guilty of a crime.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Gun offender" means any person who is convicted of a gun offense in the Circuit Court for Baltimore City or the District Court of Maryland for Baltimore City.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Gun offender" does not include a person:
whose conviction for a gun offense has been reversed on appeal or otherwise set aside pursuant to law; or
who has been pardoned by the Governor.

para.heading: Gun offense.
para.text: "Gun offense" means:
a violation of any of the following sections of the State Criminal Law Article:
§ 4-203 {Wearing, carrying, or transporting a handgun};
§ 4-204 {Use of a handgun or antique firearm in commission of a crime};
§ 4-303 {Assault [pistols] weapons – Prohibited};
§ 4-305 {Detachable magazines – Prohibited};
§ 4-305.1 {Rapid fire trigger activators – Prohibited};
§ 4-404 {Use of a machine gun in a crime of violence};
§ 4-405 {Use of a machine gun for an aggressive purpose};
§ 5-621 {Crimes involving controlled dangerous substances and paraphernalia – Use of a weapon as separate crime}; or
§ 5-622 {Firearm crimes}; or
a violation of any of the following sections of the State Public Safety Article:
§ 5-106 {License required to engage in the business of selling, renting, or transferring regulated firearms};
§ 5-123 {Dealer – Sale, rent, or transfer of a regulated firearm prior to the expiration of 7-day waiting period};
§ 5-124(a) {Non-dealer – Sale, rent, or transfer of a regulated firearm prior to the expiration of 7-day waiting period};
§ 5-125(b) {Sale, rent, or transfer of a regulated firearm to a firearm applicant whose firearm application is placed on hold};
§ 5-132(c)(1) {Dealer – sale, offer for sale, rent, or transfer a handgun manufactured on or before December 31, 2002, without an external safety lock};
§ 5-133(b) {Possession of a regulated firearm prohibited};
§ 5-133(c) {Restrictions on possession of regulated firearms – Penalty for possession by a person convicted of crime of violence};
§ 5-133(d) {Possession of regulated firearms by a person under age of 21 years prohibited};
§ 5-134 {Sale, rent, or transfer of a regulated firearm to a restricted individual};
§ 5-136 {Straw purchase of a regulated firearm};
§ 5-138 {Sale, transfer, or disposal of a stolen regulated firearm prohibited};
§ 5-140 {Transporting a regulated firearm for unlawful sale or trafficking};
§ 5-141 {Knowing participation in straw purchase};
§ 5-142 {Removal or alteration of identification mark or number on firearm};
§ 5-144 {Knowing participation in any violation of Title 1, Subtitle 5 of the State Public Safety Article}
§ 5-203 {Possession of a short-barreled rifle or short-barreled shotgun};
§ 5-205 {Possession of a rifle or shotgun by a person with mental disorder};
§ 5-206 {Person convicted of crimes of violence prohibited from possessing a rifle or shotgun}; or
§ 5-406 {Manufacture or sale of handguns}; or
a violation of any of the following sections of this City Code Article 19 {"Police Ordinances"}:
§ 59-1 {Carrying long-barrel firearms}; or
§ 59-2 {Discharging firearms}.

para.heading: Police Commissioner.
para.text: "Police Commissioner" means the Police Commissioner of Baltimore City or his or her designee.

para.heading: Commissioner may adopt.
para.text: The Police Commissioner may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: These rules and regulations may govern:
the form, content, and processing of the acknowledgment required by this subtitle;
the form and content of the registration required under this subtitle;
the documentation required to verify the content of the registration required under this subtitle;
the maintenance, use, and availability of the information that is collected by the Police Commissioner under this subtitle.

para.heading: Filing.
para.text: A copy of all rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle must be filed with the Department of Legislative Reference before they take effect.

para.heading: Registration required.
para.text: A gun offender must register with the Police Commissioner.

para.heading: Acknowledgment of duty to register.
para.text: When requested to do so, the gun offender must acknowledge, in writing, his or her duty to register under this subtitle.

para.heading: When.
para.text: The registration must be made within 48 hours of:
if the gun offender receives a sentence that does not include imprisonment, the date that the sentence is imposed;
if the gun offender receives a sentence that includes imprisonment, the date of the gun offender's release from a correctional facility;
if the gun offender is granted probation before judgment, the date that the probation before judgment is granted;
if the gun offender is found not criminally responsible and is released, the date of the gun offender's release; or

if the gun offender is found not criminally responsible and committed to the State Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, the date of the gun offender's discharge or conditional release from that commitment.

para.heading: Where.
para.text: To register, a gun offender must personally appear at an office designated by the Police Commissioner.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The registration must be in the form and contain the information that the Police Commissioner requires.

para.heading: Specific information.
para.text: The registration must specify:
the gun offender's name;
a description of the crime for which the gun offender was convicted;
the date that the gun offender was convicted;
any other name by which the gun offender has been legally known;
a list of all aliases that the gun offender has used;
identifying factors of the gun offender, including a physical description;
the gun offender's residence; and
any other information required by the rules and regulations adopted by the Police Commissioner under this subtitle.

para.heading: Signature and date.
para.text: The registration must be signed and dated by the gun offender.

para.heading: Photograph permitted.
para.text: At the time that the gun offender appears at the office, the Police Commissioner may photograph the gun offender.

para.heading: Documentation required.
para.text: The Police Commissioner may require the gun offender to provide documentation that verifies the contents of the registration

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: This section applies only to gun offenders who are residents of Baltimore City.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, within 20 calendar days after each 6-month anniversary of a gun offender's initial registration, the gun offender must personally appear at an office designated by the Police Commissioner to verify and update, as appropriate, the contents of the registration.

If a gun offender is confined to any correctional facility, hospital, or institution throughout the 20-day period described in paragraph (1) of this subsection, the gun offender must personally appear at an office designated by the Police Commissioner, within 48 hours of release, to verify and update, as appropriate, the contents of the registration.

para.heading: Update on change of residence.
para.text: A gun offender must personally appear at an office designated by the Police Commissioner to update his or her residence address and other contents of the registration:
within 10 calendar days after establishing a residence in Baltimore City;
within 10 calendar days after moving from one residence in Baltimore City to another residence in Baltimore City; and
before moving from a residence in Baltimore City and assuming a new residence out of Baltimore City.

para.heading: Photograph permitted.
para.text: At the time that the gun offender appears at the office, the Police Commissioner may photograph the gun offender.

para.heading: Documentation required.
para.text: The Police Commissioner may require the gun offender to provide documentation that verifies the contents of the registration.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The gun offender must verify the contents of the registration, as required by § 60-6 of this subtitle, for a period of 5 years from the date of the gun offender's initial registration.

para.heading: Calculation of time.
para.text: A gun offender's term of registration under this section is stayed if the gun offender is subsequently convicted and incarcerated for another gun offense.

section.heading: Sharing registration information.
section.text: The Police Commissioner may make the information collected under this subtitle available to:

para.text: any federal, state, or local law enforcement agency; and
any City agency.

section.heading: Cooperation with other agencies.
section.text: The Police Commissioner may cooperate with other federal, state and City agencies and the judiciary to facilitate implementation of this subtitle.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct.
section.text: No gun offender may:

para.text: knowingly fail to acknowledge in writing his or her duty to register under this subtitle;
fail to register as required by this subtitle or the rules and regulations adopted under it;
fail to verify information as required by this subtitle or the rules and regulations adopted under it; or
provide false information in the registration or verification required by this subtitle or the rules and regulations adopted under it.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any gun offender who violates any provision of § 60-10 of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or imprisonment for not more than 12 months or both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Arson or malicious burning offender" or "offender" means any individual who is convicted of an arson or malicious burning offense in any degree.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Arson or malicious burning offender" does not include an individual:
whose conviction for an arson or malicious burning offense has been reversed on appeal or otherwise set aside pursuant to law; or
who has been pardoned by the Governor.

para.heading: Arson or malicious burning offense.
para.text: "Arson or malicious burning offense" means a violation of any of the following sections of the State Criminal Law Article:
§ 6-102 {"Arson in the first degree"};
§ 6-103 {"Arson in the second degree"};
§ 6-104 {"Malicious burning of personal property in the first degree"};
§ 6-105 {"Malicious burning of personal property in the second degree"};
§ 6-106 {"Burning with intent to defraud"};
§ 6-107 {"Threat of arson"}; or
§ 5-622 {"Burning trash container"}.

para.heading: Commissioner
para.text: "Commissioner" means the Police Commissioner of Baltimore City or the Commissioner's designee.

para.heading: Convicted.
para.text: "Convicted" means an individual has:
been found guilty of an arson or malicious burning offense by a jury or judicial officer;
accepted a plea of guilty or nolo contendere for an arson or malicious burning offense; or
been granted probation before judgment after a finding of guilt for an arson or malicious burning offense, if the court orders compliance with this subtitle as a condition of probation.

para.heading: Correctional facility.
para.text: "Correctional facility" means a facility that is operated for the purpose of detaining or confining adults who are charged with or found guilty of a crime.

para.heading: Commissioner may adopt.
para.text: The Commissioner may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: These rules and regulations may govern:
the form, content, and processing of the acknowledgment required by this subtitle;
the form and content of the registration required under this subtitle;
the documentation required to verify the content of the registration required under this subtitle; and
the maintenance, use, and availability of the information that is collected by the Commissioner under this subtitle.

para.heading: Registration required.
para.text: An arson or malicious burning offender must register with the Commissioner.

para.heading: Acknowledgment of duty to register.
para.text: When requested to do so by a judicial officer or law enforcement officer, an offender must acknowledge, in writing, the offender's duty to register under this subtitle.

para.heading: Timing.
para.text: An offender must register with the Commission within 48 hours of:
the date the offender's sentence is imposed, if the offender receives a sentence that does not include imprisonment; or
the date of the offender's release from a correctional facility, if the offender receives a sentence that includes imprisonment.

para.heading: Location.
para.text: To register with the Commissioner, an offender must personally appear at an office designated by the Commissioner.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The registration must be in the form and contain the information that the Commissioner requires and that is required in subsection (b) of this section.

para.heading: Required information.
para.text: The registration must include the following information:
the offender's name;
the crime for which the offender was convicted;
the date on which the offender was convicted;
any other name by which the offender has been legally known;
a list of all aliases that the offender has used;
identifying factors of the offender, including a physical description;
the offender's residence; and
any other information required by the rules and regulations adopted by the Commissioner under this subtitle.

para.heading: Signature and date.
para.text: The registration must be signed and dated by the offender and the Commissioner or the Commissioner's designee.

para.heading: Photograph.
para.text: At the time that the offender appears at the office to register, the Commissioner may photograph the offender.

para.heading: Documentation required.
para.text: The Commissioner may require the offender to provide documentation that verifies the contents of the registration.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: This section applies only to offenders who are residents of Baltimore City.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, every 6 months and 20 days following the initial registration, an offender must personally appear at the designated office to verify and update the information on the registration.

If an offender is confined to any correctional facility, hospital, or similar institution throughout the final 20 days of the period described in paragraph (1) of this subsection, within 48 hours of release from the facility, hospital, or similar institution, the offender must personally appear at the designated office to verify and update the information on the registration.

para.heading: Updating registered residence.
para.text: An offender must personally appear at the designated office to update the offender's residence address and other contents of the registration:
within 10 calendar days of establishing a residence in Baltimore City;
within 10 calendar days after moving from 1 residence in Baltimore City to another residence in Baltimore City; and
before moving from a residence in Baltimore City and assuming a new residence outside of Baltimore City.

para.heading: Photograph permitted.
para.text: At the time the offender appears at the designated office to verify the registration information, the Commissioner may photograph the offender.

para.heading: Documentation required.
para.text: The Commissioner may require the offender to provide documentation that verifies the contents of the registration.

section.heading: Term of verification requirement.
section.text: The offender must verify the contents of the registration required by this subtitle for a period of 3 years from the date of the offender's initial registration.
